ORDER denying [563] Discovery Letter Brief.In the attached order, the court addresses some of the disputes that the parties raise. The main one is whether merits discovery should be stayed until the trial judge decides the class-certification motion. That case-management issue must be raised with the trial judge. Addendum: In the first iteration of this filing, the court attached the discovery letter, not the order, and now remedies that. (Beeler, Laurel) (Filed on 9/2/2022) (Additional attachment(s) added on 9/2/2022: # (1) Exhibit Order) (Beeler, Laurel). Modified on 9/2/2022 (Beeler, Laurel).

Supplemental Discovery Order.The attached order order amends the scope of the holding in the order at ECF No. 564-1. If the defendants want to stay the case, they must file a motion before the trial judge. Because their primary argument was to stay the discovery, the court allows the defendants to provide the ordinary scope objections to the discovery (such as privilege supported by a privilege log or burden). Any renewed dispute must be in a new joint letter brief. This moots the motion for reconsideration at ECF No. 566. (Beeler, Laurel) (Filed on 9/19/2022)

ORDER by Hon. Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr. DENYING Dkt. No. [238] Defendants' Motion to Deny Class Certification. The Court notes that the briefing schedule noticed by Defendants is inconsistent with Dkt. No. [232], the schedule stipulated to by the parties and set by the Court on April 12, 2021, and unfair to the Plaintiffs as it purports to require an opposition within two weeks. The Court also finds that this is not the type of unusual case in which a preemptive motion to deny certification is appropriate, efficient or helpful. See Taylor v. Shutterfly, Inc., No. 18-CV-00266-BLF, 2020 WL 1307043, at *5 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 19, 2020) (explaining that motions to deny class certification are "disfavored and may be denied as premature."). Plaintiffs are currently conducting discovery relating to class certification, and this case therefore presents a different procedural posture than Vinole v. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc., 571 F.3d 935 (9th Cir. 2009), the case upon which Defendants rely, because the plaintiffs there admitted that they "had conducted significant discovery and did not intend to propound any additional discovery seeking information from [defendant] regarding the propriety of class certification." Id. at 943. Even then, the Ninth Circuit explained that while a district court may consider a preemptive motion to deny class certification, "the better and more advisable practice for a District Court to follow is to afford the litigants an opportunity to present evidence as to whether a class action was maintainable." Id. at 942. This is especially true here given Defendants' effort to preemptively foreclose hypothetical amendments to the complaint never sought by Plaintiffs, and their suggestion that they may later oppose certification on "additional grounds." Dkt. No. 238 at 21 n.13. This denial is without prejudice to Defendants raising the same issues and arguments in their opposition to class certification. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (hsglc2S, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 5/3/2021)

ORDER ADDRESSING DISCOVERY DISPUTE IN THE LETTER BRIEF AT ECF NO. [251]. Under the court's standing order, discovery letters must be joint. This letter is not joint. The court denies it for failing to comply with the court's dispute-resolution procedures.The court understands the procedural context of the letter brief and the interplay with the discovery cutoff and Civil Local Rule 37-23. Still, the parties must comply with the court's procedures before the court will have a hearing on any dispute. The court's standing order has deadlines built in to eliminate foot-dragging and allow resolution of disputes in a short time.In any subsequent filing, the parties may refer to earlier exhibits by reference to the ECF numbers and need not refile them.In sum, the court denies the motion because it is not joint, but deems the issue timely and preserved under Civil Local Rule 37-3. By no later than May 13, 2021, the parties must confer by any means but at least by telephone. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) Therefore, mute your phone if possible and wait for the Court to address you before speaking on the line. For call clarity, parties shall NOT use speaker phone or earpieces for these calls, and where at all possible, parties shall use landlines. The parties are further advised to ensure that the Court can hear and understand them clearly before speaking at length.PLEASE NOTE: Persons granted access to court proceedings held by telephone or videoconference are reminded that photographing, recording, and rebroadcasting of court proceedings, including screenshots or other visual copying of a hearing, is absolutely prohibited. See General Order 58 at Paragraph III. NOTE REGARDING TELEPHONIC CASE MANAGEMENT CONFERENCES: All attorneys and pro se litigants appearing for a telephonic case management conference are required to dial-in at least 15 minutes before the hearing to check-in with the CRD. Order on Discovery Letter Brief

Discovery OrderGoing forward, the parties must continue to comply with the discovery procedures in the court's standing order. The court modifies the form of the discovery letter as follows: (1) the parties must certify at the top of the letter that they complied with the court's meet-and-confer requirement (including meeting in person or by videoconference) (the parties have not complied with this requirement); (2) the moving party must thereafter email its opening argument of up to two pages to the opposing party, which then must insert its opposition of up to two pages and email it back; and (3) the moving party may reply in up to one page, inserting it into the word document and emailing it back to the opposing party. Then, within two business days, the parties must confer again, at least by videoconference, to see if they can resolve their dispute. If not, they each have four to five lines for their final proposed compromises and must insert them into the letter brief. The moving party thereafter is responsible for filing the letter brief. The court directs the parties to read the standing order. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (Beeler, Laurel) (Filed on 2/4/2024)

ORDER regarding discovery issues in the letter brief at ECF No. [717]. The letter brief does not illuminate the issues sufficiently: for one, in a dense paragraph, the plaintiffs list everything they want and then attach their requests. The court thus denies the discovery without prejudice to the plaintiffs' raising the issue in a formal motion following a meaningful meet-and-confer on the issues. Within five business days, the parties must engage in that meet-and-confer in person or by videoconference. Thereafter, in a motion noticed on the ordinary five-week calendar, the plaintiffs can move to compel, but they must be specific about what they want and why it is relevant to the litigation as it exists on the date that they file the motion. Order granting [751] Motion entered by Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler.The court grants the motion: now that the litigation has been refined to more manageable form, the court agrees that the scope of the discovery in the recent motions can be revisited through the letter-brief process. This order extends only to the two recently terminated motions in favor of the letter-brief process and this dispute. The parties must confer in light of the cabined case and submit a joint letter brief with their updated positions. This is more efficient and faster than the motions process, and with the current litigation landscape, it is important to move the case along. The court expects the parties to meet and confer by any means and then at least by video conference. They cannot mail it in and must tell the court exactly how long the video conference lasted when they submit their letter briefs. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.)

Order regarding [791] Motion for Leave to File a Motion for Reconsideration re [791] entered by Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler. The court would benefit from the defendants' position on the motion for reconsideration. Ordinarily, the court would direct a joint letter because the assertion is that the context is different now. But in the interest of efficiency, the court will not require a joint letter and instead asks for the defendants' position by next Wednesday, June 5. The plaintiffs can file a two-page response by Thursday, June 6. If there are exhibits that require a chambers copy, they must be lodged in chambers by noon on Friday. The parties are reminded to use the word "discovery" when they file a discovery-related document on the docket. The usual method of flagging it (via the title "Discovery Letter Brief") was not followed. There also was no chambers copy, as required by the standing order, either to the proposed order box or by lodging the required chambers copy for a more voluminous filing. The court stumbled on the motion only because there was an administrative motion with a proposed order, which was lodged in the orders box.In any event, going forward, the court would appreciate it if the parties followed the rules. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr: Further Case Management Conference held on 8/1/2024 by Zoom videoconference. The Court and parties agree that in terms of structure for the January 2025 trial, the injunctive relief subclasses should be tried first, followed by Plaintiffs' individual claims. Within 30 days from today, the parties must submit an estimate for the number of hours required by each side to try the injunctive relief claims of the certified subclasses. Within 1 week from today (by 8/8/2024), the parties shall submit (1) a stipulation and proposed order setting a briefing schedule for the summary judgment/dispositive motions that gives the Court as much time as possible to consider the motions by the hearing date; (2) a stipulation and proposed order setting a briefing schedule on Plaintiffs' anticipated motion to certify an issue for interlocutory appeal; and (3) a list of magistrate judges that the parties mutually find suitable for conducting a settlement conference in this case. Upon receipt of their joint list, the Court will make a referral. Additionally, the parties must meet and confer about how Plaintiffs should provide notice of the access barriers they plan to litigate at trial. Finally, as to the Defendants' motion for sanctions [798], the Court takes it under submission and DENIES the motion. Total Time in Court/Digital Recording Time: 22 minutes (Assigned Transcriber: Tara Jauregui of echoreporting@yahoo.com) For Plaintiffs: Guy Wallace; Gay Grunfeld; and Mark Johnson For Defendants: Erica Rutner; Michael Jacobsen and John Bertino (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. OrderThe landscape of the litigation has changed significantly since the motion filed at ECF No. 704. Similarly, the motion at 738-3 was filed just after the latest order by the trial court. The court previously allowed a full briefing primarily because the letter briefs were unhelpful but that calculus has changed given that the litigation has changed. Thus, the court terminates the pending motions in favor of the following process. The parties must confer about the current case (cabined to six facilities) and engage in the meet-and-confer required by the court's standing order. Then, they must file separate letter briefs by issue, but must employ this process: opening letter brief of two pages by moving party emailed to opposing counsel in Word; four days later, opposing party emails two pages back; two days later, moving party emails back reply of up to one page and files the letter brief under the normal process. For exhibits, each party is limited to twenty pages each absent order of the court. Chambers copies with tabbed exhibits must be lodged. The court will order fuller briefing after reviewing the letter briefs (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (Beeler, Laurel) (Filed on 2/14/2024)

case_data.name: Eidler v. Brookdale Senior Living
case_data.plaintiff_description: Residents of the defendant facilities with disabilities who use mobility aids.
case_data.summary:
On July 13, 2017, elderly and dependent residents with physical or cognitive impairments who lived in assisted living facilities, represented by private counsel, filed this putative class action lawsuit in the US District Court of the Northern District of California under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA) and California state law against the corporation that owned the facilities. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant's California facilities and services failed to meet accessibility and usability requirements of persons with disabilities. The plaintiffs also asserted that the California facilities are understaffed, which resulted in insufficient care and services.

On August 25, 2017, the complaint was amended to include additional plaintiffs.

On September 28, 2017, the defendant filed motions to dismiss, strike, and compel arbitration. Among other things, the motions requested that the court (Judge James Donato) dismiss any claims against communities operated by the defendant in which the plaintiffs had never lived. The defendant also claimed that their residential communities were not covered under Title III of ADA, and thus the plaintiffs' claims failed as a matter of law. If not dismissed, the defendant requested language regarding the understaffing allegations be stricken as the understaffing did not suggest discrimination under ADA. The defendant sought that class allegations be stricken due to a lack of factual allegations, and alternatively sought limitations to the class definition. Additionally, the defendant sought compelled arbitration of various plaintiffs based on arbitration agreements signed by the plaintiffs or their legal representatives.

On March 29, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint. The amended complaint limited the scope of the injunctions sought to residents with mobility or visual disabilities class, and to residents with disabilities class.

On April 16, 2018, the case was reassigned to Judge Haywood Gilliam. On April 19, 2018, the defendants’ renewed their motion to compel arbitration and motioned to dismiss/strike portions of the plaintiffs’ amended complaint. On January 25, 2019, the court denied the defendants’ motion to compel arbitration, but partially granted their motion to dismiss, which compelled the plaintiffs to submit a third amended complaint on February 15, 2019 (ECF #90).

On February 25, 2019, the defendants appealed Judge Gilliam's arbitration ruling to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. They also moved to stay proceedings pending appeal, and moved to certify a question for interlocutory appeal on whether their facilities are considered public accommodations under the ADA. Judge Gilliam denied the motion to stay and denied certification of the question on June 5, 2019, finding that even though there was a controlling question of law, there was no substantial ground for difference of opinion and the interlocutory appeal would not materially advance litigation. 

On April 24, 2020, the court of appeals reversed in part, and affirmed in part the defendant's interlocutory appeal from February 25, 2019. The court affirmed denial of the defendant's motion to compel arbitration for two of the plaintiffs' ADA and state law claims, and reversed denial of the defendant's motion to compel arbitration for one of the plaintiff's state law claims. 

For the next two years, the parties litigated discovery issues. Defendants preemptively moved to deny class certification on April 30, 2021, which the court denied on May 3, 2021, finding it unfair to the plaintiffs while discovery was occurring, especially as it foreclosed hypothetical amendments to the complaint the plaintiffs never sought. Plaintiffs moved for class certification on August 18, 2021. On March 3, 2022, defendants moved to deny class certification. 

Given the large amount of discovery disputes raised by the parties, the court has yet to rule on class certification. On September 30, 2022, the defendants moved to stay discovery pending the class certification ruling. 

This case is ongoing as of December 2022.
case_data.summary_short:
On July 13, 2017, plaintiffs, elderly or dependent residents with physical or cognitive impairments who lived in the defendant's assisted living facilities, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Northern District of California under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 ("ADA") and state law against the corporation that owned the facilities. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant's California facilities and services fail to meet accessibility and usability requirements of persons with disabilities. The plaintiffs also asserted that the California facilities are understaffed, which resulted in insufficient care and services. This case is ongoing.

Currently, the case has been in discovery since July 25, 2019 ad the case has continued.

  SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECL. AND INJ. RELIEF AND DAMAGES - Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
    
 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 52   Filed 03/29/18   Page 2 of 100
 
INTRODUCTION 
1 
2  1.  Plaintiffs and the proposed Classes bring this action for declaratory and 
3  injunctive relief and damages to stop the unlawful and fraudulent practices of Brookdale Senior 
4  Living, Inc. and Brookdale Senior Living Communities, Inc. (“BROOKDALE” or 
5  “Defendants”). 
6  2.  Plaintiffs are elderly or dependent individuals living in California who have 
7  significant care needs and disabilities.  Plaintiffs and their families were overwhelmed by and 
8  required assistance with their activities of daily living including, but not limited to, assistance 
9  with managing and taking medication, housekeeping, laundry, dressing, bathing, toileting, 
10  hygiene, food preparation, and transportation.  Plaintiffs and their families and the classes they 
11  seek to represent either chose a BROOKDALE facility or chose to stay in a facility purchased by 
12  BROOKDALE because they believed BROOKDALE’s repeated promises to provide the care 
13  and assistance that would allow them to age with dignity.  Instead, Plaintiffs, their family 
14  members, and the proposed class members have all encountered in BROOKDALE a system of 
15  understaffed assisted living facilities that fails to consistently provide even the most basic level 
16  of promised care. 
17  3.  Defendant BROOKDALE has engaged in a policy and practice of violating Title 
18  III of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (“ADA”), 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., 
19  accompanying regulations, and the Unruh Civil Rights Act (“Unruh Act”), California Civil Code 
20  §§ 51 et seq.  Among other things, Defendant has violated the ADA by failing to make its 
21  assisted living facilities readily accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities even though 
22  both the ADA and the Unruh Act impose affirmative duties upon Defendants to make their 
23  assisted living facilities accessible.  As set forth below, Defendants have a policy and practice of 
24  leaving physical access barriers in place in their newly constructed, altered and/or existing 
25  facilities in violation of the ADA and the Unruh Act.  Defendants have failed to perform new 
26  construction and alterations in compliance with applicable federal and state disability access 
27  standards, including but not limited to the 1991 Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility 
28  Guidelines (“ADAAG”) and the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, and have failed to

5  6.  Defendant BROOKDALE has also engaged in a policy and practice of violating 
6  the Consumer Legal Remedies Act (“CLRA”), Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1750 et seq., committing Elder 
7  Financial Abuse, Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.30, and Unlawful, Unfair and Fraudulent 
8  Business Practices (“UCL”), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code §§ 17200 et seq.  Defendants promise to 
9  provide the elderly and disabled the “quality of life they’ve earned,” but Defendants instead 
10  engage in a scheme to defraud seniors, persons with disabilities, and their family members.  In 
11  order to induce the elderly and disabled to move into and stay at its California assisted living 
12  facilities, BROOKDALE makes misrepresentations and misleading statements and conceals 
13  material facts about the quality and availability of care available at BROOKDALE.  Reasonable 
14  consumers are misled to believe, and reasonably expect, that BROOKDALE determines each 
15  resident’s needs and staffs each facility accordingly to deliver personalized care to meet those 
16  needs.  Instead, BROOKDALE systemically understaffs its facilities, cuts caregiver hours, and 
17  fails to train workers, all to boost its profitability, while the residents in BROOKDALE’s care 
18  are forced to endure increasingly expensive monthly charges and worsening care.  The results of 
19  BROOKDALE’s callous and profit-driven approach are devastating: as multiple reports by state 
20  regulators confirm, residents are left without assistance for hours after falling, they are given the 
21  wrong medications, they are denied clean clothing, showers, and nutritious food, and they are 
22  left in their own waste for long periods of time. 
23  7.  On any given day, residents of BROOKDALE’s many California facilities live 
24  with a substantial risk that they will not receive the care and services they have paid for and that 
25  they need.  Scores of family and resident council meetings and hundreds of communications to 
26  BROOKDALE management have failed to rectify these problems, leaving Plaintiffs and the 
27  class no choice but to seek redress in this Court.

BROOKDALE FAILS TO PROVIDE FULL AND EQUAL ACCESS TO AND 
6  ENJOYMENT OF ITS FACILITIES AND SERVICES TO PERSONS WITH 
DISABILITIES IN VIOLATION OF THE ADA 
7   AND THE UNRUH CIVIL RIGHTS ACT 
Physical Access Violations 
8 
9  33.  BROOKDALE has violated Title III of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act 
10  by failing to provide full and equal access to its facilities and services.  Rooms occupied by 
11  persons with mobility disabilities and common areas at the BROOKDALE San Ramon, 
12  Windsor, Fountaingrove, Scotts Valley, and likely other facilities, do not meet federal or state 
13  accessibility standards.  Under Title III, fifty percent of the residential rooms in long-term care 
14  facilities must meet the requirements of the 1991 ADAAG or the 2010 ADA Standards.  
15  BROOKDALE’s facilities do not meet these standards. 
16  34.  There is a pattern of physical access barriers in BROOKDALE facilities, as 
17  described below: 
18  a.  Wheelchair users are placed in rooms that do not have sufficient turning 
19  space in the bathrooms or the bedroom area.  This means that they often 
20  cannot even use their bathroom unless they are able to transfer out of their 
21  wheelchair and enter without it.  Those who can enter in their wheelchair 
22  usually do not have enough space to transfer safely onto the toilet or into 
23  the shower or to use the sink or vanity space.  Some residents have given up 
24  on using their inaccessible toilet and must rely on adult briefs and 
25  caregiving staff to clean them. 
26  b.  There is no clearance for wheelchairs under the sinks and/or the sinks are 
27  too high for a wheelchair user to reach them, preventing residents from 
28  using them. 
    12   
  SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECL. AND INJ. RELIEF AND DAMAGES - Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 52   Filed 03/29/18   Page 14 of 100
 
1  c.  The grab bars that do exist in the bathrooms are not compliant with 
2  applicable access standards, and there are no roll-in showers.  Both of these 
3  barriers are safety hazards, increasing the likelihood of falls.  They also 
4  prevent most persons with mobility disabilities from bathing as 
5  independently as possible.  Some wheelchair users have stopped using their 
6  showers altogether and instead take sponge baths, hardly an adequate 
7  substitute. 
8  d.  There are barriers to using the outdoor space for the residents’ rooms, 
9  including hard-to-open sliding doors, a lip at the threshold of the door, and 
10  insufficient space to accommodate a wheelchair.  This prevents persons 
11  with mobility disabilities from using their outdoor space as persons without 
12  disabilities can. 
13  e.  The closets do not have accessible hanging and storage space, in that they 
14  are placed out of the reach of a wheelchair user.  This prevents persons with 
15  mobility disabilities from accessing their clothing and other personal items, 
16  forcing them to rely on others for assistance. 
17  f.  Kitchen countertops and sinks are too high for a wheelchair user to access, 
18  preventing those residents from fully using their kitchens. 
19  g.  Heavy doors in common areas cannot be used independently by and pose a 
20  safety risk to many persons with disabilities. 
21  35.  These physical access barriers, which residents live with on a daily basis, prevent

1  the named Plaintiffs reside. 
2  64.  Pursuant to Cal. Health & Safety Code § 1569.158(a), residential care facilities 
3  may not prohibit the formation of a family council.  California law also requires that the facility 
4  provide a meeting space for the family council, as well as a prominent, visible space for family 
5  council announcements, such as meeting notices, minutes, and newsletters.  Cal. H&S Code § 
6  1569.158(d).  Moreover, a facility must respond in writing to any written concerns or 
7  recommendations submitted by the family council within 14 days. Cal. H&S Code § 
8  1569.158(f). 
9  65.  California law also prohibits assisted living facilities from willfully interfering 
10  with the “formation, maintenance, or promotion of a family council.”  Cal. H&S Code § 
11  1569.158(i).  The law defines “willful interference” as including “discrimination or retaliation in 
12  any way against an individual as a result of his or her participation in a family council, refusal to 
13  publicize family council meetings or provide appropriate space for meetings or postings as 
14  required . . ., or failure to respond to written requests by a family council in a timely manner.  
15  Cal. H&S Code § 1569.158(i).

7  68.  Pursuant to Cal. Health & Safety Code § 1569.157(a), residential care facilities 
8  must assist the residents in establishing and maintaining a resident council.  Moreover, a facility 
9  must respond in writing to any written concerns or recommendations submitted by the resident 
10  council within 14 days. Cal. H&S Code § 1569.157(c). 
11  69.  California law also prohibits assisted living facilities from willfully interfering 
12  with the “formation, maintenance, or promotion of a resident council.”  Cal. H&S Code § 
13  1569.157(g).  The law defines “willful interference” as including “discrimination or retaliation 
14  in any way against an individual as a result of his or her participation in a resident council, 
15  refusal to publicize resident council meetings or provide appropriate space for either meetings or 
16  a bulletin board, or failure to respond to written requests by the resident council in a timely 
17  manner.”  Cal. H&S Code § 1569.157(g).   
18  70.  BROOKDALE has not responded in writing to at least four letters sent to its 
19  corporate offices by Ms. JESTRABEK-HART in her capacity as chair of the BROOKDALE 
20  Scotts Valley residents’ council.  The letters addressed the lack of adequate staffing, facility 
21  maintenance concerns, the lack of emergency signals in the laundry rooms, common room doors 
22  that are difficult to open, and the high price of meals for visitors.  The executive director at the 
23  Scotts Valley facility responded to one of the letters orally, but BROOKDALE has not 
24  responded in writing to any of the above-mentioned letters, in violation of Cal. H&S Code§ 
25  1569.157(c) and (g) .

8  under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(3) because questions of law or fact common to the 
9  class members predominate over any questions affecting individual members of the putative 
10  classes. 
11  194.  Superiority.  A class action is superior to other methods for the fair and efficient 
12  adjudication of this controversy because, inter alia: 1) individual claims by the class members 
13  would be impracticable because the costs of pursuit of such claims would far exceed what any 
14  individual class member has at stake; 2) relatively little individual litigation has been 
15  commenced over the controversies alleged in this Complaint and individual class members are 
16  unlikely to have an interest in separately prosecuting and controlling individual actions; 3) the 
17  concentration of litigation of these claims in one forum will achieve efficiency and promote 
18  judicial economy; 4) the proposed classes are manageable, and no difficulties are likely to be 
19  encountered in the management of this class action that would preclude its maintenance as a 
20  class action; 5) the proposed class members are readily identifiable from Defendants’ own 
21  records; and 6) prosecution of separate actions by individual members of the proposed class 
22  would create the risk of inconsistent or varying adjudications with respect to individual members 
23  of the proposed classes that would establish incompatible standards of conduct for 
24  BROOKDALE. 
25  195.  The Class Meets the Requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
26  23(b)(2).  BROOKDALE has acted and refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the 
27  class, making the declaratory and injunctive relief sought on behalf of the class as a whole 
28  appropriate.

documents.title: Order Denying Defendants' Motion to Stay and Motion to Certify for Interlocutory Appeal
documents.text:
Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 1 of 11
 
1   
2   
3   
4  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
5  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
6   
7  STACIA STINER, et al.,  Case No.  17-cv-03962-HSG    
 
8  Plaintiffs, 
ORDER DENYING DEFENDANTS’ 
MOTION TO STAY AND MOTION TO 
9  v. 
CERTIFY FOR INTERLOCUTORY 
  APPEAL 
10  BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING, INC., et 
al.,  Re: Dkt. Nos. 94, 99 
11 
Defendants.   
a  12     
tr in
uoro 13  Defendants Brookdale Senior Living, Inc. and Brookdale Senior Living Communities, Inc. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  (collectively, “Brookdale”) filed a motion to stay proceedings pending its appeal of the Court’s 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  order denying Defendants’ motion to compel arbitration.  Dkt. No. 94.  Brookdale also filed a 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  motion requesting the Court to certify for interlocutory appeal the question of whether Brookdale 
S d nr
ee 17  facilities are public accommodations under Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  (“ADA”).  Dkt. No. 99.  The Court finds that this matter is appropriate for disposition without oral 
19  argument and the matter is deemed submitted.  See Civil L.R. 7-1(b).  For the reasons discussed 
20  below, the Court DENIES the motion to stay proceedings and motion to certify for interlocutory 
21  appeal.    
22  I.  BACKGROUND 
23  Plaintiffs filed their second amended complaint against Brookdale for violations of the 
24  ADA, the Unruh Civil Rights Act (“Unruh Act”), the Consumer Legal Remedies Act, California 
25  Business and Professions Code §§ 7200 et seq., and California Welfare and Institutions Code 
26  § 15610, based on the conditions of Brookdale’s assisted living facilities.1  Dkt. No. 52 (“SAC”).  
27 
                                                 
1 As of the date of this Order, there are eight Plaintiffs: Stacia Stiner, Helen Carlson, Lawrence 
28 
Quinlan, Edward Boris, Bernie Jestrabek-Hart, Arthur and Patricia Lindstrom, and Ralph Schmidt. 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 2 of 11
 
1  In November 2018, Brookdale filed three motions: (1) motion to compel Plaintiffs Helen Carlson 
2  and Lawrence Quinlan to arbitrate, Dkt. No. 59; (2) motion to dismiss Plaintiffs’ SAC, Dkt. No. 
3  60; and (3) motion to strike the class allegations of Plaintiffs’ SAC, Dkt. No. 61.  The Court 
4  denied Brookdale’s motion to compel arbitration and motion to strike, and granted in part and 
5  denied in part Brookdale’s motion to dismiss.  Dkt. No. 85 (“January 25 Order”).  Brookdale 
6  appealed the Court’s order denying the motion to compel arbitration, Dkt. No. 93, and filed the 
7  present motion to stay proceedings related to Plaintiffs Carlson and Quinlan pending appeal, Dkt. 
8  No. 94.  Brookdale also filed a motion to certify for interlocutory appeal the Court’s finding that 
9  Brookdale facilities are public accommodations under the ADA.  Dkt. No. 99.   
10  II.  MOTION TO STAY 
11  A.  Court’s Order Denying Motion to Compel Arbitration  
12  Brookdale moved to compel Plaintiff Helen Carlson to arbitrate based on a 2011 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Agreement, which Plaintiffs argued was later superseded by a December 2017 Agreement.  Dkt. 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  No. 59.  In 2011, Ms. Carlson entered into a standardized residency agreement and arbitration 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  addendum before moving into a Brookdale facility.  SAC ¶ 115.  Ms. Carlson entered into a new 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  residency agreement in December 2017, under which she opted out of the arbitration provision.  
S d nr
ee 17  Dkt. No. 38-1, Ex. D at 9–12.  The Court found that the December 2017 Agreement controlled and 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  the arbitration opt-out applied to all claims arising from her stay at the Brookdale facility.  January 
19  25 Order at 6–7.  Further, based on the plain language of the arbitration provision, the Court held 
20  that the opt-out retroactively applied to the claims asserted in this lawsuit, notwithstanding that the 
21  lawsuit was filed before the December 2017 Agreement.  Id. (“The 2017 arbitration provision 
22  applies to ‘claims … whether existing or arising in the future.’”) (quoting Dkt. No. 38-1, Ex. D at 
23  10).  Therefore, by the plain language of the December 2017 Agreement, Ms. Carlson was not 
24  compelled to arbitrate her claims.   
25  As to Plaintiff Lawrence Quinlan, the Court found that there was no agency relationship 
26  between him and his son, Phillip Quinlan, at the time Phillip Quinlan signed a 2015 residency 
27  agreement containing an arbitration opt-out clause.  January 25 Order at 7–9.  Mr. Quinlan did not 
28  grant his son power of attorney until January 2016.  Dkt. No. 31-4, Ex. A.  Brookdale offered no 
2 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 3 of 11
 
1  evidence that Mr. Quinlan, either by his conduct or inaction, caused Brookdale to believe that 
2  Phillip Quinlan was acting as his agent when Phillip Quinlan executed the residency agreement.  
3  January 25 Order at 8.  The Court also rejected Brookdale’s equitable estoppel argument, as none 
4  of Plaintiffs’ claims relies on the residency agreements as valid and enforceable contracts.  Id. at 9.   
5  Based on these findings, the Court denied Brookdale’s motion to compel Plaintiffs Carlson 
6  and Quinlan to arbitrate.  Id. at 2–9.   
7  B.  Legal Standard 
8  The Ninth Circuit has held that a district court’s order denying a motion to compel 
9  arbitration does not automatically result in a mandatory stay of proceedings pending appeal of that 
10  order.  Britton v. Co-op Banking Group, 916 F.2d 1405, 1412 (9th Cir. 1990).  Instead, the district 
11  court has discretion to decide whether to stay proceedings pending appeal.  Id.  The party 
12  requesting the stay bears the burden of showing that the circumstances justify exercise of that 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  discretion.  Nken v. Holder, 556 U.S. 418, 433–34 (2009).  To determine whether the moving 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  party has met its burden, the Supreme Court articulated the following four-factor test: “(1) whether 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  the [movant] has made a strong showing that [the movant] is likely to succeed on the merits; (2) 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  whether the [movant] will be irreparably injured absent a stay; (3) whether issuance of the stay 
S d nr
ee 17  will substantially injure the other parties interested in the proceeding; and (4) where the public 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  interest lies.”  Id. at 418.  Courts in the Ninth Circuit weigh these factors with a “general 
19  balancing” or “sliding scale” approach, under which “a stronger showing of one element may 
20  offset a weaker showing of another.”  Leiva-Perez v. Holder, 640 F.3d 962, 964 (9th Cir. 2011).  
21  As to the first factor, if a movant is unable to show a ”strong likelihood of success,” then the 
22  movant must at least demonstrate that the appeal presents a “substantial case on the merits,” or 
23  that there are “serious legal questions” raised.2  Id. at 965–68.  However, under this lower 
24 
                                                 
2 Although the parties present two alternative frameworks for analyzing whether a stay in this 
25 
action is appropriate (i.e. one applied specifically to stays pending appeal in the arbitration context 
and one applied generally to stays pending appeal), courts in this district have consistently 
26 
analyzed the “substantial question” inquiry, first articulated in Britton, under the first factor in 
Nken as part of the sliding scale approach set forth in Leiva-Perez.  See, e.g., Blair v. Rent-A-Ctr., 
27 
Inc., No. C 17-02335 WHA, 2018 WL 2234049 (N.D. Cal. May 16, 2018); Jimenez v. Menzies 
Aviation Inc., No. 15-CV-02392-WHO, 2015 WL 5591722 (N.D. Cal. Sept. 23, 2015); Ward v. 
28 
Estate of Goossen, No. 14-CV-03510-TEH, 2014 WL 7273911 (N.D. Cal. Dec. 22, 2014); 
3 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 4 of 11
 
1  threshold, the movant must then demonstrate that the balance of hardships under the second and 
2  third factor tips sharply in the movant’s favor.  Id. at 970. 
3  C.  Discussion 
4  i.  Likelihood of Success or Substantial Question 
5  Brookdale argues that on appeal it raises “substantial issues in contending that its 
6  arbitration agreements with Plaintiffs Carlson and Quinlan are fully enforceable under the FAA.”  
7  Dkt. No. 94 at 5.  For Ms. Carlson, Brookdale proffers that there is a substantial issue as to 
8  whether the opt-out provision in the December 2017 “subject-matter-specific agreement” can 
9  supersede an earlier, “broader agreement to arbitrate.”  Id.  The substantial issue as to Mr. 
10  Quinlan, according to Brookdale, is whether an “implied agent may bind a principal as to 
11  arbitration” in light of “Congress’s preference for arbitration.”  Id. at 7.   
12  The Ninth Circuit has not clearly defined the phrase “substantial case on the merits,” but 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  courts in this district have interpreted the phrase to mean a case that: (1) “raises genuine matters of 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  first impression within the Ninth Circuit”; (2) may “implicate a constitutional question”; or (3) 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  “otherwise address[es] a pressing legal issue which urges that the Ninth Circuit hear the case.”  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Morse, 2013 WL 123610, at *3 (citing cases in this district granting stays because there was a 
S d nr
ee 17  substantial question as to whether state precedent is preempted by the FAA); Blair, 2018 WL 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  2234049, at *2 (finding substantial question as to whether a California Supreme Court case is 
19  preempted by the FAA); Ward, 2014 WL 7273911, at *3 (finding substantial question in case 
20  where contracts were poorly-constructed and contained ambiguous and inconsistent provisions); 
21  Zaborowski, 2013 WL 1832638, at *2 (finding substantial question as to the applicability of a 
22  Supreme Court case to California law governing arbitration agreements).  The Court will follow 
23  the same approach, as it is consistent with public policy recognizing that while a stay is an 
24  “intrusion into the ordinary processes of administration and judicial review,” there may be 
25  instances when enforcement of a determination should be stayed to allow the reviewing court 
26 
                                                                                                                                                                
27 
Zaborowski v. MHN Gov’t Servs., Inc., No. C 12-05109 SI, 2013 WL 1832638 (N.D. Cal. May 1, 
2013); Morse v. Servicemaster Glob. Holdings, Inc., No. C 08-03894, 2013 WL 123610 (N.D. 
28 
Cal. Jan. 8, 2013). 
4 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 5 of 11
 
1  ample time to consider the merits and prevent “irreparable injury to the parties or to the public.”  
2  See Nken, 556 U.S. at 427; Scripps-Howard Radio v. F.C.C., 316 U.S. 4, 9 (1942).  Any other 
3  approach would allow a party to indefinitely stall trial “simply by bringing a frivolous motion to 
4  compel arbitration.”  Britton, 916 F.2d at 1412.   
5  The Court does not find that Brookdale’s arguments constitute substantial questions that 
6  raise genuine matters of first impression with the Ninth Circuit, implicate a constitutional 
7  question, or otherwise address a pressing legal issue.  See Morse, 2013 WL 123610, at *3.  Rather, 
8  the Court resolved Brookdale’s arguments through application of well-settled contract and agency 
9  principles.  With respect to Ms. Carlson, Brookdale asserts that the Court was incorrect as a matter 
10  of contract interpretation when it read the opt-out in the December 2017 Agreement to apply to 
11  “[a]ny and all claims arising out of, or in any way relating to, this Agreement or your stay at the 
12  Community.”  Dkt. No. 94 at 6 (quoting January 25 Order at 6).  But that is exactly what the 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  arbitration provision said, in unambiguous, plain language: 
Cfi
 tla  
ciC 14  AGREEMENT  TO  ARBITRATE.  [  ]  Any  and  all  claims  or 
rts fo controversies  arising  out  of,  or  in  any  way  relating  to,  this 
iD tc 15  Agreement or your stay at the Community, excluding any action for 
 sir
et eviction,  and  including  disputes  regarding  interpretation  of  this 
tatsiD 16  Agreement, whether arising out of State or Federal law, whether 
S d nr existing or arising in the future, whether for statutory, compensatory 
ee 17  or punitive damages and whether sounding in breach of contract, tort 
th
intr or breach of statutory duties, irrespective of the basis for the duty or 
Uo
N 18  the  legal  theories  upon  which  the  claim  is  asserted,  shall  be 
submitted to binding arbitration, as provided below, and shall not be 
19  filed in a court of law. 
20  Dkt. No. 38-1, Ex. D at 10.  The appeal thus poses no serious legal issues of contract 
21  interpretation, and Brookdale’s position is contrary to the plain language of the provision itself.  
22  See Morse, 2013 WL 123610, at *3 (“Notwithstanding the FAA’s strong preference for arbitration 
23  where contracts raise doubts, the Court held that ‘here there is no doubt.’  The Court relied only on 
24  the four corners of the contract, and did not rest on or implicate any constitutional issue”).3    
25    Brookdale’s second purportedly substantial question is whether an implied agent may bind 
26 
                                                 
27 
3 Brookdale cites several cases for the proposition that this Court’s holding is inconsistent with 
other courts’ rulings.  Dkt. No. 94 at 6.  The Court sees no inconsistency, as those cases (a) are not 
28 
controlling and (b) involved distinguishable facts.   
5 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 6 of 11
 
1  a principal to arbitration.  Dkt. No. 94 at 6.  But Brookdale’s reading of the January 25 Order is 
2  misplaced.  The Court did not address whether an implied agent may bind a principal to 
3  arbitration, because it held that Phillip Quinlan, Mr. Quinlan’s son, was not an agent under 
4  principles of “apparent authority.”  January 25 Order at 8.  As Brookdale correctly notes, it “is 
5  black letter law that agency may generally be implied,” but the Court held that Brookdale offered 
6  no evidence that Mr. Quinlan, either by conduct or inaction, “caused Brookdale to believe Phillip 
7  Quinlan was acting as his agent when he executed the 2015 residency agreement.”  Id. at 8.  
8  Brookdale seems to suggest that Congress’s “preference for arbitration” compels the Court to 
9  disregard well-established agency principles and presume an implied agency relationship within 
10  the arbitration context, even when there simply is no evidence of such a relationship.  Dkt. No. 94 
11  at 7.  But the Court is doubtful that the law requires that result, and Brookdale’s cases do not stand 
12  for such a position.  See id. at 7 (citing Kindred Nursing Ctrs. Ltd. P’ship v. Clark, 137 S. Ct. 1421 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  (2017)).  In Kindred, the Supreme Court reversed a lower court’s decision declining to give effect 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  two arbitration agreements executed by individuals holding powers of attorney.  Kindred Nursing, 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  137 S. Ct. at 1425.  The lower court’s decision was based on a state rule that the Supreme Court 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  held violated the FAA.  Id. at 1426–27 (“The Kentucky Supreme Court’s clear-statement rule … 
S d nr
ee 17  fails to put arbitration agreements on an equal plane with other contracts.”).  Notably here, Phillip 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Quinlan did not hold his father’s power of attorney at the time he signed the residency agreement.  
19  Dkt. No. 31-4, Ex. A.   
20     The first factor therefore does not weigh in favor of a stay.   
21  ii.  Irreparable Harm to Defendants 
22  Next, Brookdale contends that “[t]here can be no question that Brookdale will be 
23  irreparably harmed if a stay is denied,” because it would have to incur the cost of litigation 
24  pending appeal, thereby defeating the cost-limiting purpose of arbitration.  Dkt. No. 94 at 9–10.  
25  However, litigation will move forward regardless of the outcome of Brookdale’s appeal, as the 
26  appeal only concerns two Plaintiffs.  Because Plaintiffs will continue with discovery and class 
27  certification briefing, the cost of litigating this case is not likely to be meaningfully reduced if only 
28 
6 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 7 of 11
 
1  two Plaintiffs are compelled to arbitrate.4  Other courts in this district have held that litigation 
2  expense, when the moving party must continue litigating regardless of the outcome of the appeal, 
3  is not sufficient to establish irreparable harm.  See, e.g., Blair, 2018 WL 2234049, at *2 (“[The] 
4  appeal concerns only a portion of the claims at issue in this case.  Regardless of the outcome of the 
5  appeal, [defendant] will incur the costs of litigating [the] non-arbitrable claims”); Ambrosio v. 
6  Cogent Commc’ns, Inc., No. 14-CV-02182-RS, 2016 WL 7888024, at *3 (N.D. Cal. Sept. 21, 
7  2016) (“Yet, this litigation will move forward regardless of the outcome of [defendant’s] appeal 
8  … [a]s such, the cost of litigating this case is not likely to be less”); Jimenez, 2015 WL 5591722, 
9  at *4 (“Regardless of the outcome of its appeal, [defendant] must continue to litigate the remaining 
10  claims; therefore, if I grant this partial stay [defendant] will still incur the potential costs or delays 
11  associated with litigation”).  Brookdale does not convincingly explain why the same is not true 
12  here. 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Because Brookdale fails to satisfy the first two crucial factors, the Court need not reach the 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  remaining factors in its analysis.  See Mount Graham Coal. v. Thomas, 89 F.3d 554, 558 (9th Cir. 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  1996) (declining to address the remaining factors where first factor was not satisfied); see also 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  Ambrosio, 2016 WL 7888024, at *3; Morse, 2013 WL 123610, at *4.   
S d nr
ee 17  *                         *                         * 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  For the foregoing reasons, Brookdale’s motion to stay pending appeal of the Court’s order 
19  denying the motion to compel arbitration is DENIED. 
20  III.  MOTION TO CERTIFY FOR INTERLOCUTORY APPEAL 
21  A.  Court’s Order Finding Brookdale Facilities Are Public Accommodations  
22  In the Court’s January 25 Order, the Court denied Brookdale’s motion to dismiss 
23  Plaintiffs’ Title III ADA and Unruh Act claims.5  January 25 Order at 12–14.  In so doing, it held 
24 
                                                 
4 Brookdale cites to a Seventh Circuit case, Bradford-Scott Data Corp. v. Physician Comput. 
25 
Network, Inc., 128 F.3d 504 (7th Cir. 1997), to support its assertion that the time and expense of 
litigation constitutes irreparable harm in the arbitration context.  Dkt. No. 94 at 10.  Beyond the 
26 
fact that litigation expense does not constitute irreparable harm in this particular case, the Court 
also notes that Bradford-Scott rejects, and is in direct conflict with, the Ninth Circuit’s holding in 
27 
Britton.  See Bradford-Scott, 128 F.3d at 506.   
5 The analysis underlying the ADA claims also applies to the Unruh Act claims.  Molski v. M.J. 
28 
Cable, Inc., 481 F.3d 724, 731 (9th Cir. 2007) (“Any violation of the ADA necessarily constitutes 
7 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 8 of 11
 
1  that Brookdale facilities are public accommodations subject to the ADA.  Id. at 12.  According to 
2  the SAC, Brookdale facilities are assisted living facilities, also called “Residential Care Facilities 
3  for the Elderly (“RCFEs”), and offer “room, board and daily assistance for seniors and persons 
4  with disabilities.”  SAC ¶ 28.  The assistance offered includes “preparing meals, shopping, 
5  transportation, preparing and taking medication, housekeeping, laundry, bathing, toileting, 
6  grooming, dressing, and others.”  Id.  Brookdale’s own SEC filings represented that all “of our 
7  communities are required to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act, or ADA.”  Dkt. No 
8  26-1, Ex. A at 32.   
9  The Court found unpersuasive Brookdale’s argument that despite its facilities providing 
10  skilled nursing “and other, higher levels of medical care,” the facilities are more similar to private 
11  apartment complexes than assisted living and nursing facilities.  January 25 Order at 12.  
12  Brookdale cited no case in which similar facilities were exempted from ADA compliance.  Id.  
a 
tr in
uoro 13  Instead, the Court found convincing Plaintiffs’ argument that the facilities are similar to assisted 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  living and skilled nursing facilities, such as those at issue in Hubbard v. Twin Oaks Health & 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Rehab Ctr., 408 F. Supp. 2d 923 (E.D. Cal 2004) and Herriot v. Channing House, No. C 06-
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  6323JF, 2009 WL 225418 (N.D. Cal. Jan. 29, 2009), and are therefore public accommodations.  
S d nr
ee 17  Id.   
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Brookdale now asks the Court to certify for interlocutory appeal the question of whether 
19  the facilities are public accommodations under the ADA.  Dkt. No. 99.  Should the Court grant the 
20  motion to certify for interlocutory appeal, Brookdale also seeks a partial stay pending the appeal.  
21  Id.    
22  B.  Legal Standard 
23  Under the “final judgment rule,” codified in 28 U.S.C. § 1291, the courts of appeal have 
24  jurisdiction over “appeals from all final decisions of the district courts of the United States.”  28 
25  U.S.C. § 1291.  Appellate review before a final judgment is only appropriate in “exceptional cases 
26  where decision of an interlocutory appeal might avoid protracted and expensive litigation.”  U.S. 
27 
                                                                                                                                                                
28 
a violation of the Unruh Act.”).   
8 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 9 of 11
 
1  Rubber Co. v. Wright, 359 F.2d 784, 785 (9th Cir. 1966).  A district court may only certify an 
2  order for interlocutory appeal if the moving party demonstrates that: (1) the issue to be certified 
3  “involves a controlling question of law”; (2) there is a “substantial ground for difference of 
4  opinion”; and (3) “an immediate appeal from the order may materially advance the ultimate 
5  termination of the litigation.”  28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).  The requirements of § 1292(b) are 
6  jurisdictional, meaning if the appeal does not present circumstances satisfying the statutory 
7  prerequisites, the reviewing court cannot allow the appeal.  Couch v. Telescope Inc., 611 F.3d 629, 
8  633 (9th Cir. 2009).   
9  Because § 1292(b) is a departure from the final judgment rule, this exception “must be 
10  construed narrowly.”  James v. Price Stern Sloan, Inc., 283 F.3d 1064, 1068 n.6 (9th Cir. 2002).  
11  The decision to certify an issue for interlocutory appeal is discretionary, Swint v. Chambers Cty. 
12  Comm’n, 514 U.S. 35, 36 (1995), and the district court should apply the requirements “strictly” 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  and certify for interlocutory appeal only when “exceptional circumstances” justify a departure 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  from the well-established policy of postponing appellate review until after a final judgment.  See 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Coopers & Lybrand v. Livesay, 437 U.S. 463, 475 (1978).  The party seeking certification bears 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  the burden of demonstrating that the requirements are satisfied and that such a departure is 
S d nr
ee 17  warranted.  Id.   
th
intr
Uo
N 18  C.  Discussion 
19  i.  Controlling Question of Law  
20  The issue to be certified must be a “controlling question of law.”  28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).  
21  The moving party must show that “resolution of the issue on appeal could materially affect the 
22  outcome of litigation in the district court.”  In re Cement Antitrust Litig., 673 F.2d 1020, 1026 (9th 
23  Cir. 1981).  Brookdale contends, and Plaintiffs concede, that this issue is controlling because only 
24  if the facilities are public accommodations subject to Title III of the ADA may “any ADA or 
25  Unruh Act claims … proceed at all.”  Dkt. No. 99; see Dkt. No. 120 at 1 n.1.  The Court agrees 
26  and finds that Brookdale has satisfied the first factor.  However, Brookdale has not satisfied the 
27  remaining two factors and the Court therefore declines to exercise its discretion to certify the issue 
28  for interlocutory appeal.      
9 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 10 of 11
 
1  ii.  Substantial Ground for Difference of Opinion 
2  The second requirement under § 1292(b) is that there is a “substantial ground for 
3  difference of opinion” on the issue the moving party seeks to certify for interlocutory appeal.  “A 
4  party’s strong disagreement with the Court’s ruling” is not enough.  Couch, 611 F.3d at 633.  
5  “That settled law might be applied differently does not establish a substantial ground for 
6  difference of opinion.”  Id.  Rather, “courts must examine to what extent the controlling law is 
7  unclear.”  Id.  A substantial ground for difference of opinion exists where “the circuits are in 
8  dispute on the question and the court of appeals of the circuit has not spoken on the point, if 
9  complicated questions arise under foreign law, or if novel and difficult questions of first 
10  impression are presented.”  Id. (quotations and citation omitted).  However, “just because a court 
11  is the first to rule on a particular question or just because counsel contends that one precedent 
12  rather than another is controlling does not mean there is such a substantial difference of opinion as 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  will support an interlocutory appeal.”  Id.  
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  Brookdale argues that there is a “substantial ground for difference of opinion” because the 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Ninth Circuit has not addressed the specific issue concerning Brookdale’s facilities and the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  “legislative history and statutory text indicat[e] that residential communities such as Brookdale’s 
S d nr
ee 17  are not ‘public accommodations’ under the ADA.”  Dkt. No. 99 at 5–9.  The Court disagrees.  
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Brookdale repeats the arguments the Court rejected in denying the motion to dismiss, but that 
19  simply reflects its “strong disagreement” with the Court’s holding.  See Couch, 611 F.3d at 633.  
20  The Court has already found that the facilities are more similar to the assisted living and skilled 
21  nursing facilities at issue in Hubbard and Herriot than to private residences.  January 25 Order at 
22  13–14.  Brookdale disagrees and characterizes the facilities differently than they are described in 
23  the SAC (and in its own SEC filings).  But this is just an argument that the Court misapplied the 
24  existing law to the facts alleged, which is clearly insufficient to show a “substantial ground for 
25  difference of opinion.”  See Couch, 611 F.3d at 633; see also United States v. Wen-Bing Soong, 
26  No. C-13-4088 EMC, 2014 WL 988632, at *1 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 10, 2014) (citing cases).  
27  iii.  Materially Advance Litigation 
28  Under the third factor, the Court must determine whether an interlocutory appeal on this 
10 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 130   Filed 06/05/19   Page 11 of 11
 
1  issue would “materially advance the ultimate termination of the litigation.”  28 U.S.C. § 1292(b).  
2  “The ultimate question is whether permitting an interlocutory appeal would minimize the total 
3  burdens of litigation on parties and the judicial system by accelerating or at least simplifying trial 
4  court proceedings.” Allen v. ConAgra Foods, Inc., No. 3:13-CV-01279-WHO, 2019 WL 1466889, 
5  at *3 (N.D. Cal. Feb. 6, 2019) (quotations and citation omitted).  
6  The Court agrees with Plaintiffs that Brookdale’s appeal would not materially advance the 
7  ultimate termination of the litigation.  See Dkt. No. 120 at 12.  As Plaintiffs observe, even if the 
8  ADA and Unruh Act claims were terminated at this juncture, Plaintiffs’ other claims are still 
9  pending and litigation would go forward regardless.  Id.  An interlocutory appeal therefore would 
10  not accelerate the pace of this litigation and would not minimize either party’s burden.  The Court 
11  also cannot say that permitting appeal of the ADA claim would materially narrow the scope and 
12  duration of discovery, as Plaintiffs appear likely to conduct the same or very similar discovery for 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  their other pending claims.  See Dkt. No. 120 at 13.  If anything, certifying the issue for 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  interlocutory appeal could delay the ultimate termination of this case.  See Shurance v. Planning 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  Control Int’l, Inc., 839 F.2d 1347, 1348 (9th Cir. 1988)  
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  *                         *                         * 
S d nr
ee 17  Accordingly, the Court DENIES Brookdale’s motion to certify for interlocutory appeal. 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  IV.  CONCLUSION 
19  The Court DENIES Brookdale’s motion to stay, Dkt. No. 94, and DENIES Brookdale’s 
20  motion to certify for interlocutory appeal, Dkt. No. 99.  The Court SETS a case management 
21  conference for July 16, 2019 at 2:00 p.m.  The Court DIRECTS the parties to file on or before 
22  July 9, 2019, a joint case management statement with a proposed class certification briefing 
23  schedule.   
24  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
25  Dated:  6/5/2019
26  ______________________________________ 
HAYWOOD S. GILLIAM, JR. 
27 
United States District Judge
