FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
    
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 2 of 91
 
INTRODUCTION 
1
2 1.  Plaintiffs and the proposed Classes bring this action for declaratory and injunctive 
3 relief and damages to stop the unlawful and fraudulent practices of Brookdale Senior Living, Inc. 
4 and Brookdale Senior Living Communities, Inc. (“BROOKDALE” or “Defendants”). 
5 2.  Plaintiffs are elderly or dependent individuals living in California who have 
6 significant care needs and disabilities.  Plaintiffs and their families were overwhelmed by and 
7 required assistance with their activities of daily living including, but not limited to, assistance with 
8 managing and taking medication; housekeeping; laundry; dressing; bathing; toileting; hygiene; 
9 food preparation; and transportation.  Plaintiffs and their families and the classes they seek to 
10 represent either chose a BROOKDALE facility or chose to stay in a facility purchased by 
11 BROOKDALE because they believed BROOKDALE’s repeated promises to provide the care and 
12 assistance that would allow them to age with dignity.  Instead, Plaintiffs, their family members, 
13 and the proposed class members have all encountered in BROOKDALE a system of understaffed 
14 assisted living facilities that fails to consistently provide even the most basic level of promised 
15 care. 
16 3.  Defendant BROOKDALE has engaged in a policy and practice of violating Title 
17 III of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (“ADA”), 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et seq., 
18 accompanying regulations, and the Unruh Civil Rights Act (“Unruh Act”), California Civil Code 
19 §§ 51 et seq.  Among other things, Defendant has violated the ADA by failing to make its assisted 
20 living facilities readily accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities.  Defendants’ assisted 
21 living facilities are characterized by multiple, pervasive physical access barriers that limit or deny 
22 full and equal access to persons with disabilities. 
23 4.  Moreover, Defendant has failed to make reasonable modifications to its policies, 
24 practices and procedures that are necessary for persons with disabilities to have full and equal 
25 access to and enjoyment of the services, goods, facilities, privileges, advantages and 
26 accommodations provided by BROOKDALE’s facilities.  Defendants’ goods, services, facilities, 
27 privileges, advantages, or accommodations include providing assistance with activities of daily 
28   1
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 3 of 91
 
1 living (assistance with eating, housekeeping and laundry, bathing, grooming, dressing, toileting, 
2 personal hygiene, provision of nutritious meals), medication management (ordering and storage of 
3 medications, assistance taking medications), social and recreational activities (group exercise, 
4 games, movies, scenic drives, happy hours and social mixers, and assistance with arrangements for 
5 utilization of local resources), and transportation to and coordination of off-site services.  Plaintiffs 
6 have specifically requested that Defendant BROOKDALE make reasonable modifications to its 
7 staffing policies, practices and procedures for its assisted living facilities in order to ensure that 
8 there is staffing in sufficient numbers and with adequate training to provide timely and effective 
9 assistance and care to residents with disabilities.  Despite the fact that such modifications are 
10 necessary to ensure that residents with disabilities receive full and equal access to and enjoyment 
11 of Defendants’ goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations, and despite 
12 the fact that such modifications will not result in any fundamental alteration to BROOKDALE’s 
13 public accommodations, Defendant has refused to do so. 
14 5.  In addition, Defendant has violated the ADA by failing and refusing to provide 
15 residents with mobility disabilities with full and equal access to and enjoyment of its 
16 transportation services.  Further, Defendant has discriminated against residents with disabilities by 
17 failing to provide them with an emergency evacuation plan that is designed for and reasonably 
18 calculated to ensure the prompt and effective evacuation of persons with disabilities in the event of 
19 emergency. 
20 6.  Defendant BROOKDALE has also engaged in a policy and practice of violating the 
21 Consumer Legal Remedies Act (“CLRA”), Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1750 et seq., committing Elder 
22 Financial Abuse, Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.30, and Unlawful, Unfair and Fraudulent 
23 Business Practices (“UCL”), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code §§ 17200 et seq.  Defendants promise to 
24 provide the elderly and disabled the “quality of life they’ve earned,” but Defendants instead 
25 engage in a scheme to defraud seniors, persons with disabilities, and their family members.  In 
26 order to induce the elderly and disabled to move into and stay at its California assisted living 
27 facilities, BROOKDALE makes misrepresentations and misleading statements and conceals 
28   2
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 4 of 91
 
1 material facts about the quality and availability of care available at BROOKDALE.  Reasonable 
2 consumers are misled to believe, and reasonably expect, that BROOKDALE determines each 
3 resident’s needs and staffs each facility accordingly to deliver personalized care to meet those 
4 needs.  Instead, BROOKDALE systemically understaffs its facilities, cuts caregiver hours, and 
5 fails to train workers, all to boost its profitability, while the residents in BROOKDALE’s care are 
6 forced to endure increasingly expensive monthly charges and worsening care.  The results of 
7 BROOKDALE’s callous and profit-driven approach are devastating: as multiple reports by state 
8 regulators confirm, residents are left without assistance for hours after falling, they are given the 
9 wrong medications, they are denied clean clothing, showers, and nutritious food, and they are left 
10 in their own waste for long periods of time. 
11 7.  On any given day, residents of BROOKDALE’s many California facilities live 
12 with a substantial risk that they will not receive the care and services they have paid for and that 
13 they need.  Scores of family and resident council meetings and hundreds of communications to 
14 BROOKDALE management have failed to rectify these problems, leaving Plaintiffs and the class 
15 no choice but to seek redress in this Court. 
16 8.  This lawsuit seeks to end this systemic discrimination against persons with 
17 disabilities by requiring Defendant to provide them with full and equal access to and enjoyment of 
18 BROOKDALE’s facilities, services, goods, privileges, advantages and accommodations.  This 
19 action seeks to require that Defendants staff their facilities with a sufficient number of adequately 
20 trained staff to ensure that residents with disabilities are provided with full and equal access to and 
21 enjoyment of the services specified in BROOKDALE’s own resident assessments.  In addition, 
22 this action seeks to require that Defendants provide assistive living facilities that are readily 
23 accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities as required by the ADA.  Further, Plaintiffs 
24 seek injunctive relief requiring Defendants to provide full and equal access to and enjoyment of 
25 Defendants’ transportation services and activities.  Plaintiffs also seek injunctive relief requiring 
26 Defendants to provide adequate emergency planning and evacuation procedures for residents with 
27 disabilities.  With respect to the CLRA, the UCL and the Elder Financial Abuse statute, this action 
28   3
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 5 of 91
 
1 seeks to require Defendant to disclose to prospective and current residents, their family members 
2 or responsible parties, and the class that BROOKDALE’s existing staffing policies and procedures 
3 preclude it from providing its residents with all the care and services they have been promised and 
4 are paying for.  Further, this action seeks to enjoin BROOKDALE from charging residents or their 
5 responsible parties monthly fees based on their Personal Service Plans until BROOKDALE 
6 implements staffing policies and procedures that enable it to deliver those services on a consistent 
7 basis. 
8 9.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law and, unless BROOKDALE is 
9 preliminarily and permanently enjoined, Plaintiffs will continue to suffer irreparable harm as a 
10 result of being denied full and equal access to and enjoyment of BROOKDALE’s goods, services, 
11 facilities, privileges, advantages, and/or accommodations.  Plaintiffs seek declaratory and 
12 injunctive relief and statutory and actual damages as set forth below against BROOKDALE for its 
13 policy and practice of denying Plaintiffs full and equal access to and enjoyment of its services and 
14 facilities and violating the ADA and its accompanying regulations, the Unruh Act, the CLRA, 
15 committing Elder Financial Abuse, and engaging in Unlawful, Unfair and Fraudulent Business 
16 Practices.  Plaintiffs also seek recovery of reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs and litigation expenses 
17 under federal and state law. 
18 EXHAUSTION OF PRE-LAWSUIT PROCEDURES FOR STATE LAW CLAIMS 
19 10.  By letter dated June 2, 2017, Plaintiffs notified Defendants of Plaintiffs’ intent to 
20 file suit against it based on violations of the Consumer Legal Remedies Act, as required by 
21 California Civil Code § 1782.  BROOKDALE received the letter on June 6, 2017.  More than 30 
22 days have passed since BROOKDALE’s receipt, and BROOKDALE has not corrected or 
23 remedied the violations alleged in the notice and herein. 
24 11.  Though they were not required to do so, Plaintiffs also notified BROOKDALE of 
25 its multiple violations of Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 1201 et 
26 seq., the Unruh Civil Rights Act, California’s elder financial abuse law, and California’s Unfair 
27 Competition Law. 
28   4
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 6 of 91
 
JURISDICTION 
1
2 12.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction of this action pursuant to  
3 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1343(a)(3)-(4).  The Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et 
4 seq., presents federal questions and confers jurisdiction on this Court over Plaintiffs’ claims 
5 regardless of the amount in controversy.  This Court also has subject matter jurisdiction of this 
6 action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1332(d)(2)(A) because this is a class action in which the proposed 
7 class includes at least 100 members, the amount in controversy exceeds $5,000,000, exclusive of 
8 interests and costs, and at least one putative class member is a citizen of a state different from one 
9 of the defendants.  Plaintiffs seek damages in the amount of a minimum $9,000 per class member 
10 and believe that the class consists of over 5,000 persons, making the amount in controversy well in 
11 excess of $5,000,000.  BROOKDALE is a Delaware corporation with its principal place of 
12 business in Tennessee, making it a citizen of both Delaware and Tennessee, and each of the named 
13 Plaintiffs are citizens of the State of California.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1367, this Court has 
14 supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs’ pendent claims under California law. 
15 13.  Defendants are subject to personal jurisdiction in this Court because Defendants 
16 have sufficient minimum contacts in California, or otherwise intentionally avail themselves of the 
17 California market through ownership and/or management of assisted living facilities located in 
18 California, derivation of substantial revenues from California, and other activities, so as to render 
19 the exercise of jurisdiction over Defendants by the California courts consistent with the traditional 
20 notions of fair play and substantial justice. 
21 VENUE 
22 14.  Venue is proper in the Northern District of California pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
23 § 1391(b), because the acts upon which this action is based occurred in part in this District within 
24 the counties of Alameda, Contra Costa, Lake, Monterey, Napa, San Mateo, Santa Clara, and 
25 Sonoma. 
26
27
28   5
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 7 of 91
 
1 15.  A substantial part of the events or omissions which gave rise to Plaintiffs’ claims 
2 arose in the County of Sonoma and thus, pursuant to Civil Local Rules 3-2(c) and (d), assignment 
3 to the San Francisco Division of the District Court for the Northern District of California is proper. 
4 THE PARTIES 
5 16.  Plaintiff PATRICIA EIDLER is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
6 meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult and an elder 
7 pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 15610.23 and 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled 
8 person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
9 § 1761(d).  PATRICIA EIDLER is 82 years old.  She needs assistance with the following 
10 activities of daily living: housekeeping, laundry, dressing, bathing, managing medications, 
11 transportation, and preparing nutritious meals.  She uses a walker and a wheelchair for mobility.  
12 PATRICIA EIDLER is and has been a resident of BROOKDALE San Ramon since approximately 
13 April 2013.  She is a resident of Contra Costa County in the State of California.  CHRISTOPHER 
14 WILLIAM EIDLER (“CHRIS EIDLER”) is her son and holds power of attorney.  Simultaneous 
15 with the filing of this complaint, Plaintiffs are filing an application for the appointment of CHRIS 
16 EIDLER as PATRICIA EIDLER’s guardian ad litem for the purposes of prosecuting this lawsuit. 
17 17.  Plaintiff STACIA STINER is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
18 meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult pursuant to 
19 Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.23; a disabled person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(g); and a 
20 consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d).  She needs assistance with the following activities 
21 of daily living: housekeeping, laundry, dressing, bathing, managing medications, toileting, and 
22 transportation.  She uses a wheelchair for mobility.  STACIA STINER has been a resident of 
23 BROOKDALE San Ramon since approximately February 2016.  She is a resident of Contra Costa 
24 County in the State of California. 
25 18.  Plaintiff MARY-CATHERINE JONES is a qualified person with disabilities within 
26 the meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult and an 
27 elder pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 15610.23 and 15610.27; a senior citizen and a 
28   6
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 8 of 91
 
1 disabled person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. 
2 Civ. Code § 1761(d).  MARY-CATHERINE JONES is 78 years old.  She has been diagnosed with 
3 cognitive impairments and needs assistance with the following activities of daily living: bathing, 
4 dressing, managing medications, housekeeping, laundry, and food preparation.  MARY-
5 CATHERINE JONES is and has been a resident of BROOKDALE Fountaingrove since 
6 approximately January 2013.  She is a resident of Sonoma County in the State of California.  
7 KELLY CLAPPER is MARY-CATHERINE JONES’s daughter and has had her power of 
8 attorney since October 2005.  Simultaneous with the filing of this lawsuit, Plaintiffs are filing a 
9 motion for the appointment of KELLY CLAPPER as the guardian ad litem of MARY-
10 CATHERINE JONES for the purposes of prosecuting this lawsuit. 
11 19.  Plaintiff HELEN CARLSON is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
12 meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult and an elder 
13 pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 15610.23 and 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled 
14 person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
15 § 1761(d).  HELEN CARLSON is 93 years old.  She needs assistance with the following activities 
16 of daily living: managing medications, transferring, toileting, bathing, dressing, grooming, 
17 transportation, food preparation and meal setup, housekeeping, and laundry.  She uses a 
18 wheelchair for mobility.  HELEN CARLSON is and has been a resident of BROOKDALE 
19 Fountaingrove since approximately October 2011.  She is a resident of Sonoma County in the 
20 State of California.  JOAN CARLSON is HELEN CARLSON’s daughter-in-law and has had her 
21 power of attorney since December 2006.  Simultaneous with the filing of this lawsuit, Plaintiffs 
22 are filing a motion for the appointment of JOAN CARLSON as the guardian ad litem of HELEN 
23 CARLSON for the purposes of prosecuting this lawsuit. 
24 20.  Plaintiff BONITA HAGER is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
25 meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult and an elder 
26 pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 15610.23 and 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled 
27 person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
28   7
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 9 of 91
 
1 § 1761(d).  BONITA HAGER is 65 years old.  She needs assistance with the following activities 
2 of daily living: housekeeping, laundry, toileting, dressing, bathing, pushing her wheelchair, 
3 transportation, and preparing nutritious meals.  She uses a wheelchair for mobility.  BONITA 
4 HAGER is and has been a resident of BROOKDALE San Ramon since approximately May 2013.  
5 She is a resident of Contra Costa County in the State of California. 
6 21.  Plaintiff LAWRENCE QUINLAN is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
7 meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  He is also a dependent adult and an elder 
8 pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code §§ 15610.23 and 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled 
9 person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
10 § 1761(d).  LAWRENCE QUINLAN is 87 years old.  He uses a wheelchair for mobility and has 
11 dementia.  LAWRENCE QUINLAN stayed at the facility at BROOKDALE Hemet for respite on 
12 several occasions between 2013 and 2015.  He became a long-term resident of the assisted living 
13 at BROOKDALE Hemet on approximately September 13, 2015 and left the facility on or about 
14 April 30, 2017.  He is a currently a resident of an unrelated assisted living facility in Riverside 
15 County in the State of California.  LORESIA VALLETTE is LAWRENCE QUINLAN’S 
16 granddaughter and shares power of attorney with Mr. QUINLAN’s son, Phillip Quinlan.  Ms. 
17 VALLETTE has filed an application to be appointed Mr. QUINLAN’s guardian ad litem for the 
18 purposes of prosecuting this lawsuit.   
19 22.  Defendant BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING, INC. is a corporation organized 
20 under the laws of the State of Delaware with its principal place of business in Brentwood, 
21 Tennessee. 
22 23.  Defendant BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING COMMUNITIES, INC. is a 
23 corporation organized under the laws of the State of Delaware with its principal place of business 
24 in Brentwood, Tennessee. 
25 24.  BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING, INC. and BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING 
26 COMMUNITIES, INC. will be referred to collectively as “BROOKDALE” or “Defendants.” 
27 BROOKDALE owns, manages, and/or operates approximately eighty-nine (89) assisted living 
28   8
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 10 of 91
 
1 facilities throughout California.  It is the largest chain of senior living facilities in California and in 
2 the United States. 
3 25.  Defendants DOES 1-100 are sued herein under fictitious names because Plaintiffs 
4 do not presently know their true names and capacities.  Plaintiffs will seek leave to amend this 
5 Complaint to allege their true names and capacities when such are discovered.  Plaintiffs allege 
6 that each of these Defendants was responsible in some capacity for the events alleged herein, or is 
7 a necessary party for obtaining appropriate relief.  Plaintiffs are informed and believe and thereon 
8 allege that in carrying out each of the acts and violations alleged in this Complaint, each 
9 Defendant acted as an agent, principal, and/or representative for each other Defendant. 
10 FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
11 26.  BROOKDALE is the largest provider of assisted living for senior citizens and 
12 persons with disabilities in the nation and has the largest number of assisted living facility 
13 residents within the state of California.  On information and belief, Plaintiffs allege that there are 
14 more than 5,000 residents in Defendants’ eighty-nine facilities in California. 
15 27.  Assisted living facilities, also called Residential Care Facilities for the Elderly 
16 (“RCFEs”), offer room, board and daily assistance for seniors and persons with disabilities in 
17 certain activities of daily living (“ADLs”), such as preparing meals, shopping, transportation, 
18 preparing and taking medication, housekeeping, laundry, bathing, toileting, grooming, dressing, 
19 and others. 
20 28.  Assisted living facilities are intended to provide a level of care appropriate for 
21 those who are unable to live by themselves, but who do not have medical conditions requiring 
22 more extensive nursing care. 
23 29.  In recent years, BROOKDALE has increasingly been accepting and retaining more 
24 residents with conditions and care needs that were once handled almost exclusively in skilled 
25 nursing facilities.  This has allowed it to increase not only the potential resident pool but also the 
26 amounts of money charged to residents and/or their family members. 
27  
28   9
FIRST AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
Case No. 17-cv-03962-JD 
   
 

Case 3:17-cv-03962-JD   Document 20   Filed 08/25/17   Page 11 of 91
 
1 30.  At BROOKDALE facilities, residents are charged a base rate, which includes 
2 room, board, and basic maintenance, housekeeping, laundry, dining services, planned social and 
3 recreational programs, scheduled transportation services, staffing 24 hours a day, observation and 
4 consultation, and assistance with access to outside services.  BROOKDALE uses its resident 
5 assessment system to assess each resident before admission and then again periodically throughout 
6 residency and/or whenever there is a change of the resident’s condition.  By performing these 
7 assessments, BROOKDALE determines what additional services a resident needs, such as 
8 assistance with ADLs, and develops a Personal Service Plan for the resident.  Each additional 
9 need, or service, is assigned a monthly Personal Service Rate, which is added onto the resident’s 
10 base rate.  The more personal services determined by BROOKDALE to be needed by a resident, 
11 the more money BROOKDALE charges that resident. 
12 31.  Every month, BROOKDALE sends each resident or his or her legal representative 
13 an invoice for services that BROOKDALE represents it will provide in the following month.  
14 These invoices reflect the monthly rate for the Basic Services set forth in BROOKDALE’s 
15 standard residency agreements, the Personal Service Rate that is based on each resident’s Personal 
16 Service Plan, and any adjustments.  On information and belief, these monthly invoices range from 
17 approximately $4,000 to $10,000 per person per month. 
18 32.  On information and belief, as of January 1, 2016, BROOKDALE increased the 
19 Basic Service Rate and Personal Service Rate for residents in its California facilities by roughly

7 facilities, do not meet federal or state accessibility standards.  Under Title III, fifty percent of the 
8 residential rooms in long-term care facilities must meet the requirements of the 1991 ADAAG or 
9 the 2010 ADA Standards.  BROOKDALE’s facilities do not meet these standards.

16 usually do not have enough space to transfer safely onto the toilet or into 
17 the shower or to use the sink or vanity space.  Some residents have given up 
18 on using their inaccessible toilet and must rely on adult briefs and 
19 caregiving staff to clean them.

22 using them.

26 prevent most persons with mobility disabilities from bathing as 
27 independently as possible.  Some wheelchair users have stopped using their

5 180.  Congress explicitly stated that the purpose of the ADA is to provide “a clear and 
6 comprehensive national mandate for the elimination of discrimination against individuals with 
7 disabilities” and “clear, strong, consistent, enforceable standards addressing discrimination against 
8 individuals with disabilities.” 42 U.S.C. § 12101(b) (1)-(2). 
9 181.  Title III of the ADA provides in pertinent part: “[N]o individual shall be 
10 discriminated against on the basis of disability in the full and equal enjoyment of the goods, 
11 services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations of any place of public 
12 accommodation by any person who owns, leases, or leases to, or operates a place of public 
13 accommodation.”  42 U.S.C. § 12182.

8 Physical Access Barriers 
9 192.  Plaintiffs allege on information and belief that many of Defendants’ facilities were 
10 designed and constructed after January 26, 1993, thus triggering access requirements under Title 
11 III of the ADA.  The ADA prohibits designing and constructing facilities for first occupancy after 
12 January 26, 1993 that are not readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities when 
13 it was structurally practicable to do so.  42 U.S.C. § 12183(a)(1).  BROOKDALE has violated the 
14 ADA by designing and constructing their facilities in a manner that does not comply with federal 
15 disability access design standards including the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility 
16 Guidelines (“ADAAG”) even though it was structurally practicable to do so. 
17 193.  Plaintiffs allege on information and belief that Defendants’ facilities were altered 
18 after January 26, 1993, thus triggering access requirements under Title III of the ADA.  The ADA 
19 prohibits altering facilities after January 26, 1993 in a manner that is not readily accessible to, and 
20 usable by, individuals with disabilities when it was structurally practicable to do so.  42 U.S.C. 
21 § 12183(a)(2).  Here, Defendants violated the ADA by altering its assisted living facilities after 
22 January 26, 1993 in a manner that did not comply with the ADAAG even though it was 
23 structurally practicable to do so.  Specifically, Defendants have failed to ensure that the areas of 
24 alteration complied with the ADAAG, and that the path of travel to the areas of alteration 
25 complied with the ADAAG. 
26 194.  The removal of each of the barriers complained of by Plaintiffs herein was at all 
27 times “readily achievable” under the standards of §§ 12181 and 12182 of the ADA.

    Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
 

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 2 of 110
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  Plaintiffs and the proposed Classes bring this action for declaratory and 
3  injunctive relief and damages to stop the unlawful and fraudulent practices of Brookdale 
4  Senior Living, Inc. and Brookdale Senior Living Communities, Inc. (“BROOKDALE” or 
5  “Defendants”). 
6  2.  Plaintiffs are elderly or dependent individuals living in California who have 
7  significant care needs and disabilities.  Plaintiffs and their families were overwhelmed by 
8  and required assistance with their activities of daily living including, but not limited to, 
9  assistance with managing and taking medication, housekeeping, laundry, dressing, bathing, 
10  toileting, hygiene, food preparation, and transportation.  Plaintiffs and their families and 
11  the classes they seek to represent either chose a BROOKDALE facility or chose to stay in 
12  a facility purchased by BROOKDALE because they believed BROOKDALE’s repeated 
13  promises to provide the care and assistance that would allow them to age with dignity.  
14  Instead, Plaintiffs, their family members, and the proposed class members have all 
15  encountered in BROOKDALE a system of understaffed assisted living facilities that fails 
16  to consistently provide even the most basic level of promised care. 
17  3.  Defendant BROOKDALE has engaged in a policy and practice of violating 
18  Title III of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (“ADA”), 42 U.S.C. §§ 12101 et 
19  seq., accompanying regulations, and the Unruh Civil Rights Act (“Unruh Act”), California 
20  Civil Code §§ 51 et seq.  Among other things, Defendant has violated the ADA by failing 
21  to make its assisted living facilities readily accessible to and usable by persons with 
22  disabilities even though both the ADA and the Unruh Act impose affirmative duties upon 
23  Defendants to make their assisted living facilities accessible.  As set forth below, 
24  Defendants have a policy and practice of leaving physical access barriers in place in their 
25  newly constructed, altered and/or existing facilities in violation of the ADA and the Unruh 
26  Act.  Defendants have failed to perform new construction and alterations in compliance 
27  with applicable federal and state disability access standards, including but not limited to 
28  the 1991 Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (“ADAAG”) and the 
  1  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 3 of 110
 
1  2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design, and have failed to evaluate their newly 
2  constructed and/or altered assisted living facilities to identify and remediate non-compliant 
3  and inaccessible construction and alterations therein.  Defendants have also failed and 
4  refused to identify and remove physical access barriers from their existing assisted living 
5  facilities where such barrier removal was readily achievable within the meaning of the 
6  ADA.  As a result of Defendants’ corporate policies and practices regarding disability 
7  access, Defendants’ assisted living facilities are characterized by multiple, pervasive 
8  physical access barriers that limit or deny full and equal access to persons with disabilities. 
9  4.  Moreover, Defendants have failed to make reasonable modifications to its 
10  policies, practices and procedures that are necessary for persons with disabilities to have 
11  full and equal access to and enjoyment of the services, goods, facilities, privileges, 
12  advantages and accommodations provided by BROOKDALE’s facilities.  Defendants’ 
13  goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, and/or accommodations include 
14  providing assistance with activities of daily living (assistance with eating, housekeeping 
15  and laundry, bathing, grooming, dressing, toileting, personal hygiene, provision of 
16  nutritious meals), medication management (ordering and storage of medications, assistance 
17  taking medications), social and recreational activities (group exercise, games, movies, 
18  scenic drives, happy hours and social mixers, and assistance with arrangements for 
19  utilization of local resources), and transportation to and coordination of off-site services.  
20  Plaintiffs have specifically requested that Defendant BROOKDALE make reasonable 
21  modifications to its staffing policies, practices and procedures for its assisted living 
22  facilities in order to ensure that there is staffing in sufficient numbers and with adequate 
23  training to provide timely and effective assistance and care to residents with disabilities.  
24  Despite the fact that such modifications are necessary to ensure that residents with 
25  disabilities receive full and equal access to and enjoyment of Defendants’ goods, services, 
26  facilities, privileges, advantages, and/or accommodations, and despite the fact that such 
27  modifications will not result in any fundamental alteration to BROOKDALE’s public 
28  accommodations, Defendants have refused to do so. 
  2  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 4 of 110
 
1  5.  In addition, Defendants have violated the ADA by failing and refusing to 
2  provide residents with mobility disabilities with full and equal access to and enjoyment of 
3  its transportation services.  Further, Defendants have discriminated against residents with 
4  disabilities by failing to provide them with an emergency evacuation plan that is designed 
5  for and reasonably calculated to ensure the prompt and effective evacuation of persons 
6  with disabilities in the event of emergency. 
7  6.  Defendant BROOKDALE has also engaged in a policy and practice of 
8  violating the Consumer Legal Remedies Act (“CLRA”), Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1750 et seq., 
9  committing Elder Financial Abuse, Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.30, and Unlawful, 
10  Unfair and Fraudulent Business Practices (“UCL”), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code §§ 17200 et 
11  seq.  Defendants promise to provide the elderly and disabled the “quality of life they’ve 
12  earned,” but Defendants instead engage in a scheme to defraud seniors, persons with 
13  disabilities, and their family members.  In order to induce the elderly and disabled to move 
14  into and stay at its California assisted living facilities, BROOKDALE makes 
15  misrepresentations and misleading statements and conceals material facts about the quality 
16  and availability of care available at BROOKDALE.  Reasonable consumers are misled to 
17  believe, and reasonably expect, that BROOKDALE determines each resident’s needs and 
18  staffs each facility accordingly to deliver personalized care to meet those needs.  Instead, 
19  BROOKDALE systemically understaffs its facilities, cuts caregiver hours, and fails to 
20  train workers, all to boost its profitability, while the residents in BROOKDALE’s care are 
21  forced to endure increasingly expensive monthly charges and worsening care.  The results 
22  of BROOKDALE’s callous and profit-driven approach are devastating: as multiple reports 
23  by state regulators confirm, residents are left without assistance for hours after falling, they 
24  are given the wrong medications, they are denied clean clothing, showers, and nutritious 
25  food, and they are left in their own waste for long periods of time. 
26  7.  On any given day, residents of BROOKDALE’s many California facilities 
27  live with a substantial risk that they will not receive the care and services they have paid 
28  for and that they need.  Scores of family and resident council meetings and hundreds of 
  3  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 5 of 110
 
1  communications to BROOKDALE management have failed to rectify these problems, 
2  leaving Plaintiffs and the class no choice but to seek redress in this Court. 
3  8.  This lawsuit seeks to end this systemic discrimination against persons with 
4  disabilities by requiring Defendants to provide them with full and equal access to and 
5  enjoyment of BROOKDALE’s facilities, services, goods, privileges, advantages and 
6  accommodations.  This action seeks to require that Defendants staff their facilities with a 
7  sufficient number of adequately trained staff to ensure that residents with disabilities are 
8  provided with full and equal access to and enjoyment of the services specified in 
9  BROOKDALE’s own resident assessments.  In addition, this action seeks to require that 
10  Defendants provide assistive living facilities that are readily accessible to and usable by 
11  persons with disabilities as required by the ADA.  Further, Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief 
12  requiring Defendants to provide full and equal access to and enjoyment of Defendants’ 
13  transportation services and activities.  Plaintiffs also seek injunctive relief requiring 
14  Defendants to provide adequate emergency planning and evacuation procedures for 
15  residents with disabilities.  With respect to the CLRA, the UCL and the Elder Financial 
16  Abuse statute, this action seeks to require Defendants to disclose to prospective and current 
17  residents, their family members or responsible parties, and the class that BROOKDALE’s 
18  existing staffing policies and procedures preclude it from providing its residents with all 
19  the care and services they have been promised and are paying for.  Further, this action 
20  seeks to enjoin BROOKDALE from charging residents or their responsible parties 
21  monthly fees based on their Personal Service Plans until BROOKDALE implements 
22  staffing policies and procedures that enable it to deliver those services on a consistent 
23  basis. 
24  9.  Plaintiffs have no adequate remedy at law and, unless BROOKDALE is 
25  preliminarily and permanently enjoined, Plaintiffs will continue to suffer irreparable harm 
26  as a result of being denied full and equal access to and enjoyment of BROOKDALE’s 
27  goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, and/or accommodations.  Plaintiffs seek 
28  declaratory and injunctive relief and statutory and actual damages as set forth below 
  4  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 6 of 110
 
1  against BROOKDALE for its policy and practice of denying Plaintiffs full and equal 
2  access to and enjoyment of its services and facilities and violating the ADA and its 
3  accompanying regulations, the Unruh Act, and the CLRA, for committing Elder Financial 
4  Abuse, and for engaging in Unlawful, Unfair and Fraudulent Business Practices.  Plaintiffs 
5  also seek recovery of reasonable attorneys’ fees, costs and litigation expenses under 
6  federal and state law. 
7  EXHAUSTION OF PRE-LAWSUIT PROCEDURES FOR STATE LAW CLAIMS 
8  10.  By letter dated June 2, 2017, Plaintiffs notified Defendants of Plaintiffs’ 
9  intent to file suit against it based on violations of the Consumer Legal Remedies Act, as 
10  required by California Civil Code § 1782.  BROOKDALE received the letter on June 6, 
11  2017.  More than 30 days have passed since BROOKDALE’s receipt, and BROOKDALE 
12  has not corrected or remedied the violations alleged in the notice and herein. 
13  11.  Though they were not required to do so, Plaintiffs also notified 
14  BROOKDALE of its multiple violations of Title III of the Americans with Disabilities 
15  Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 1201 et seq., the Unruh Civil Rights Act, California’s elder financial 
16  abuse law, and California’s Unfair Competition Law. 
17  JURISDICTION 
18  12.  This Court has subject matter jurisdiction of this action pursuant to  
19  28 U.S.C. §§ 1331, 1343(a)(3)-(4).  The Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. 
20  §§ 12101 et seq., presents federal questions and confers jurisdiction on this Court over 
21  Plaintiffs’ claims regardless of the amount in controversy.  This Court also has subject 
22  matter jurisdiction of this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1332(d)(2)(A) because this is a 
23  class action in which the proposed class includes at least 100 members, the amount in 
24  controversy exceeds $5,000,000, exclusive of interests and costs, and at least one putative 
25  class member is a citizen of a state different from one of the defendants.  Plaintiffs seek 
26  damages in the amount of a minimum $9,000 per class member and believe that the class 
27  consists of over 5,000 persons, making the amount in controversy well in excess of 
28  $5,000,000.  BROOKDALE is a Delaware corporation with its principal place of business 
  5  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 7 of 110
 
1  in Tennessee, making it a citizen of both Delaware and Tennessee, and each of the named 
2  Plaintiffs are citizens of the State of California.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1367, this Court 
3  has supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiffs’ pendent claims under California law. 
4  13.  Defendants are subject to personal jurisdiction in this Court because 
5  Defendants have sufficient minimum contacts in California, or otherwise intentionally 
6  avail themselves of the California market through ownership and/or management of 
7  assisted living facilities located in California, derivation of substantial revenues from 
8  California, and other activities, so as to render the exercise of jurisdiction over Defendants 
9  by the California courts consistent with the traditional notions of fair play and substantial 
10  justice. 
11  VENUE 
12  14.  Venue is proper in the Northern District of California pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 
13  § 1391(b), because the acts upon which this action is based occurred in part in this District 
14  within the counties of Alameda, Contra Costa, Lake, Monterey, Napa, San Mateo, Santa 
15  Clara, Santa Cruz, and Sonoma. 
16  15.  A substantial part of the events or omissions which gave rise to Plaintiffs’ 
17  claims arose in the County of Sonoma and thus, pursuant to Civil Local Rules 3-2(c) and 
18  (d), assignment to the Oakland Division of the District Court for the Northern District of 
19  California is proper. 
20  THE PARTIES 
21  16.  Plaintiff STACIA STINER is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
22  meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also a dependent adult 
23  pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.23; a disabled person pursuant to Cal. Civ. 
24  Code § 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d).  Ms. STINER is 48 
25  years old.  She needs assistance with the following activities of daily living: housekeeping, 
26  laundry, dressing, bathing, managing medications, toileting, and transportation.  She uses a 
27  wheelchair for mobility.  STACIA STINER has been a resident of BROOKDALE San 
28  Ramon since approximately February 2016.  She is a resident of Contra Costa County in 
  6  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 8 of 110
 
1  the State of California. 
2  17.  Plaintiff HELEN CARLSON was a qualified person with disabilities within 
3  the meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She was also an elder pursuant 
4  to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled person pursuant to 
5  Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d).  
6  HELEN CARLSON died on January 19, 2019.  At the time of her death, Ms. CARLSON 
7  was 95 years old.  Prior to her death, she needed assistance with the following activities of 
8  daily living: managing medications, transferring, toileting, bathing, dressing, grooming, 
9  transportation, food preparation and meal setup, housekeeping, and laundry.  She used a 
10  wheelchair for mobility.  At the time of her death, HELEN CARLSON was and had been a 
11  resident of BROOKDALE Fountaingrove since approximately October 2011.  She was a 
12  resident of Sonoma County in the State of California.   
13  18.  Plaintiff LAWRENCE QUINLAN is a qualified person with disabilities 
14  within the meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  He is also an elder 
15  pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled person 
16  pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
17  § 1761(d).  LAWRENCE QUINLAN is 88 years old.  He uses a wheelchair for mobility 
18  and has dementia.  LAWRENCE QUINLAN stayed at the facility at BROOKDALE 
19  Hemet for respite on several occasions between 2013 and 2015.  He became a long-term 
20  resident of the assisted living at BROOKDALE Hemet on approximately September 13, 
21  2015 and left the facility on or about April 30, 2017.  He is a currently a resident of an 
22  unrelated assisted living facility in Riverside County in the State of California.  LORESIA 
23  VALLETTE is LAWRENCE QUINLAN’S granddaughter.  Since January 25, 2016, she 
24  and her uncle Phillip Quinlan—who is Mr. QUINLAN’s son—have shared power of 
25  attorney for Mr. QUINLAN.  On September 22, 2017, this Court appointed Ms. 
26  VALLETTE as Mr. QUINLAN’s guardian ad litem for the purposes of prosecuting this 
27  lawsuit.   
28  19.  Plaintiff EDWARD BORIS was a qualified person with disabilities within 
  7  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 9 of 110
 
1  the meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  He was also an elder pursuant to 
2  Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.27; a senior citizen and a disabled person pursuant to Cal. 
3  Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d).  He 
4  was an assisted living resident at BROOKDALE Fountaingrove from September 2015 
5  through July 2016.  He was then a resident of the skilled nursing facility at BROOKDALE 
6  Fountaingrove.  Mr. BORIS died on September 14, 2018.  At the time of his death, Mr. 
7  BORIS was 86 years old.  During his time as an assisted living resident at BROOKDALE 
8  Fountaingrove, EDWARD BORIS used a walker and wheelchair.  At the time of his death, 
9  he was a resident of Sonoma County in the State of California.  MICHELE LYTLE is 
10  EDWARD BORIS’s daughter.  Ms. LYTLE has held Mr. BORIS’s power of attorney 
11  since 2011 and has taken action on his behalf as his attorney in fact since 2015.  On 
12  January 17, 2019, the Court appointed MICHELE LYTLE as the guardian ad litem of 
13  EDWARD BORIS for the purposes of prosecuting this lawsuit.  MICHELE LYTLE is the 
14  successor-in-interest of EDWARD BORIS, and a successor-in-interest declaration will be 
15  filed shortly.  
16  20.  Plaintiff PATRICIA “PAT” LINDSTROM is the wife of ARTHUR “ART” 
17  LINDSTROM.  ART LINDSTROM died on February 23, 2018, and PAT LINDSTROM 
18  is his successor-in-interest.  A successor-in-interest declaration was filed concurrently with 
19  the Second Amended Complaint.  See ECF No. 52-1.  At all times relevant to this 
20  complaint, Mr. LINDSTROM was a qualified person with disabilities within the meaning 
21  of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  He was also an elder pursuant to Cal. Welf. 
22  & Inst. Code § 15610.27; a senior citizen and disabled person pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
23  §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d). Mr. 
24  LINDSTROM was 83 years old when he died.  He suffered from diabetes, kidney failure, 
25  heart disease, sleep apnea, and incontinence; used a cane to walk; and experienced 
26  dementia-related cognitive impairment, including general memory loss, difficulty 
27  remembering words, and difficulty speaking when under pressure.  He needed assistance 
28  with the following activities of daily living: bathing, shaving, administration of 
  8  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG 
 
  
[3351751.3] THIRD AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF AND DAMAGES 
  

Case 4:17-cv-03962-HSG   Document 90   Filed 02/15/19   Page 10 of 110
 
1  medication, dressing, laundry, and preparing nutritious meals.  He was a resident of 
2  BROOKDALE Scotts Valley from approximately November 2015 until his death.  PAT 
3  LINDSTROM is a resident of Santa Cruz County in the State of California. 
4  21.  Plaintiff RALPH SCHMIDT is a qualified person with disabilities within the 
5  meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  He is also a dependent adult 
6  pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.23; a disabled person pursuant to Cal. Civ. 
7  Code § 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code § 1761(d).  RALPH 
8  SCHMIDT is 54 years old, is blind, and has significant cognitive impairments, including 
9  short-term memory loss.  Both his blindness and cognitive impairments are the result of a 
10  traumatic brain injury suffered more than 20 years ago.  Mr. SCHMIDT has a court-
11  appointed conservator who manages his financial, medical, and legal affairs.  He needs 
12  assistance with the following activities of daily living: housekeeping, laundry, navigating 
13  when outside of his dwelling, preparing nutritious meals, and transportation.  
14  Mr. SCHMIDT was an assisted living resident at the facility currently known as 
15  BROOKDALE Tracy from approximately September 2011 through October 30, 2017.  He 
16  currently resides at an assisted living facility not affiliated with BROOKDALE and is a 
17  resident of Stanislaus County in the State of California.  HEATHER FISHER is a 
18  professional fiduciary and has held a license from the California Professional Fiduciaries 
19  Bureau since March 14, 2014.  On August 17, 2017, the Superior Court of San Joaquin 
20  County appointed Ms. FISHER to serve as conservator for RALPH SCHMIDT, replacing 
21  Mary F. Gallagher who had been Mr. SCHMIDT’s conservator since approximately 
22  November 2011.  The Court appointed Ms. FISHER and Mr. SCHMIDT’s guardian ad 
23  litem for the purpose of prosecuting this lawsuit on January 17, 2019. 
24  22.  Plaintiff BERNIE JESTRABEK-HART is a qualified person with disabilities 
25  within the meaning of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights Act.  She is also an elder 
26  pursuant to Cal. Welf. & Inst. Code § 15610.27; a senior citizen and disabled person 
27  pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code §§ 1761(f), 1761(g); and a consumer pursuant to Cal. Civ. Code 
28  § 1761(d).  BERNIE JESTRABEK-HART is 73 years old.  She needs assistance with the 
  9  Case No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG

6  Physical Access Violations 
7  34.  BROOKDALE has violated Title III of the ADA and the Unruh Civil Rights 
8  Act by failing to provide full and equal access to its facilities and services.  Rooms 
9  occupied by persons with mobility disabilities and common areas at the BROOKDALE 
10  San Ramon, Windsor, Fountaingrove, Scotts Valley, and likely other facilities, do not meet 
11  federal or state accessibility standards.  Under Title III, fifty percent of the residential 
12  rooms in long-term care facilities must meet the requirements of the 1991 ADAAG or the 
13  2010 ADA Standards.  BROOKDALE’s facilities do not meet these standards. 
14  35.  There is a pattern of physical access barriers in BROOKDALE facilities, as 
15  described below: 
16  a.  Wheelchair users are placed in rooms that do not have sufficient 
17  turning space in the bathrooms or the bedroom area.  This means that 
18  they often cannot even use their bathroom unless they are able to 
19  transfer out of their wheelchair and enter without it.  Those who can 
20  enter in their wheelchair usually do not have enough space to transfer 
21  safely onto the toilet or into the shower or to use the sink or vanity 
22  space.  Some residents have given up on using their inaccessible toilet 
23  and must rely on adult briefs and caregiving staff to clean them. 
24  b.  There is no clearance for wheelchairs under the sinks and/or the sinks 
25  are too high for a wheelchair user to reach them, preventing residents 
26  from using them. 
27  c.  The grab bars that do exist in the bathrooms are not compliant with 
28  applicable access standards, and there are no roll-in showers.  Both of

12  Retaliation Against Resident Councils and Their Members 
13  64.  Pursuant to Cal. Health & Safety Code § 1569.157(a), residential care 
14  facilities must assist the residents in establishing and maintaining a resident council.  
15  Moreover, a facility must respond in writing to any written concerns or recommendations 
16  submitted by the resident council within 14 days. Cal. H&S Code § 1569.157(c). 
17  65.  California law also prohibits assisted living facilities from willfully 
18  interfering with the “formation, maintenance, or promotion of a resident council.”  Cal. 
19  H&S Code § 1569.157(g).  The law defines “willful interference” as including 
20  “discrimination or retaliation in any way against an individual as a result of his or her 
21  participation in a resident council, refusal to publicize resident council meetings or provide 
22  appropriate space for either meetings or a bulletin board, or failure to respond to written 
23  requests by the resident council in a timely manner.”  Cal. H&S Code § 1569.157(g).

27  adequate staffing, facility maintenance concerns, the lack of emergency signals in the 
28  laundry rooms, common room doors that are difficult to open, and the high price of meals

6  fact common to the class members predominate over any questions affecting individual 
7  members of the putative classes. 
8  207.  Superiority.  A class action is superior to other methods for the fair and 
9  efficient adjudication of this controversy because, inter alia: 1) individual claims by the 
10  class members would be impracticable because the costs of pursuit of such claims would 
11  far exceed what any individual class member has at stake; 2) relatively little individual 
12  litigation has been commenced over the controversies alleged in this Complaint and 
13  individual class members are unlikely to have an interest in separately prosecuting and 
14  controlling individual actions; 3) the concentration of litigation of these claims in one 
15  forum will achieve efficiency and promote judicial economy; 4) the proposed classes are 
16  manageable, and no difficulties are likely to be encountered in the management of this 
17  class action that would preclude its maintenance as a class action; 5) the proposed class 
18  members are readily identifiable from Defendants’ own records; and 6) prosecution of 
19  separate actions by individual members of the proposed class would create the risk of 
20  inconsistent or varying adjudications with respect to individual members of the proposed 
21  classes that would establish incompatible standards of conduct for BROOKDALE. 
22  208.  The Class Meets the Requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 
23  23(b)(2).  BROOKDALE has acted and refused to act on grounds generally applicable to 
24  the class, making the declaratory and injunctive relief sought on behalf of the class as a 
25  whole appropriate.

19  public accommodation.”  42 U.S.C. § 12182.

1  Physical Access Barriers 
2  225.  Plaintiffs allege on information and belief that many of Defendants’ facilities 
3  were designed and constructed after January 26, 1993, thus triggering access requirements 
4  under Title III of the ADA.  The ADA prohibits designing and constructing facilities for 
5  first occupancy after January 26, 1993 that are not readily accessible to and usable by 
6  individuals with disabilities when it was structurally practicable to do so.  42 U.S.C. 
7  § 12183(a)(1).  BROOKDALE has violated the ADA by designing and constructing their 
8  facilities in a manner that does not comply with federal disability access design standards 
9  including the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines (“ADAAG”) and 
10  the 2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design (“2010 ADA Standards”) even though it 
11  was structurally practicable to do so. 
12  226.  Plaintiffs allege on information and belief that Defendants’ facilities were 
13  altered after January 26, 1993, thus triggering access requirements under Title III of the 
14  ADA.  The ADA prohibits altering facilities after January 26, 1993 in a manner that is not 
15  readily accessible to, and usable by, individuals with disabilities when it was structurally 
16  practicable to do so.  42 U.S.C. § 12183(a)(2).  Here, Defendants violated the ADA by 
17  altering its assisted living facilities after January 26, 1993 in a manner that did not comply 
18  with the ADAAG or the 2010 ADA Standards even though it was structurally practicable 
19  to do so.  Specifically, Defendants have failed to ensure that the areas of alteration 
20  complied with the ADAAG or the 2010 ADA Standards, and that the path of travel to the 
21  areas of alteration complied with the ADAAG or the 2010 ADA Standards. 
22  227.  Additionally, Defendants have failed to remove physical access barriers in 
23  their facilities which existed prior to January 26, 1993 when removal of those barriers was 
24  “readily achievable,” in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 12182(b)(2)(A)(iv). 
25  228.  The removal of each of the barriers complained of by Plaintiffs herein was at 
26  all times “readily achievable” under the standards of §§ 12181 and 12182 of the ADA.

3  8.  For statutory damages pursuant to California Civil Code § 1780(a) and (b) 
4  for the False or Misleading Statements class; 
5  9.  For actual damages according to proof, excepting any damages for personal 
6  injury, emotional distress and/or wrongful death suffered by the named Plaintiffs or any 
7  class member; 
8  10.  For restitution and any other monetary relief permitted by law; 
9  11.  For punitive damages; 
10  12.  For treble damages pursuant to California Civil Code §§ 52(a) and 3345; 
11  13.  For pre-judgment and post-judgment interest according to law; 
12  14.  Award to Plaintiffs all costs of this proceeding, including reasonable 
13  attorneys’ fees costs and litigation expenses, as provided by law;

15  sufficient to rectify the acts and omissions alleged herein; and,

documents.text:
CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  11  ooff  66
FILED
 
NOT FOR PUBLICATION 
   
UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS  APR 24 2020 
 
 
MOLLY C. DWYER, CLERK 
FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT  U.S. COURT OF APPEALS 
 
STACIA STINER; et al.,     No.  19-15334  
       
          Plaintiffs-Appellees,   D.C. No. 4:17-cv-03962-HSG  
     
   v.     
   MEMORANDUM*  
BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING, INC.; 
BROOKDALE SENIOR LIVING 
COMMUNITIES, INC.,  
  
          Defendants-Appellants. 
 
Appeal from the United States District Court 
for the Northern District of California 
Haywood S. Gilliam, Jr., District Judge, Presiding 
 
Submitted March 25, 2020**  
San Francisco, California 
 
Before:  GOULD, CHRISTEN, and BRESS, Circuit Judges. 
 
  Brookdale Senior Living, Inc., and Brookdale Senior Living Communities, 
Inc.  (collectively,  Brookdale)  appeal  the  district  court’s  denial  of  Brookdale’s 
motion to compel Helen Carlson and Lawrence Quinlan to arbitrate.  We have 
 
    *    This disposition is not appropriate for publication and is not precedent 
except as provided by Ninth Circuit Rule 36-3. 
  
    **    The panel unanimously concludes this case is suitable for decision 
without oral argument.  See Fed. R. App. P. 34(a)(2). 
        

CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  22  ooff  66
jurisdiction under 9 U.S.C. § 16.  Reviewing de novo, Murphy v. DirecTV, Inc., 
724 F.3d 1218, 1224 (9th Cir. 2013), we affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
  Carlson and Quinlan were residents at Brookdale.  They, among others, sued 
Brookdale as part of a putative class action, alleging claims under the Americans 
with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), the Unruh Civil Rights Act (Unruh Act), the 
Consumer Legal Remedies Act (CLRA), section 17200, et seq., of the California 
Business and Professions Code (UCL), and section 15610.30 of the California 
Welfare and Institutions Code.  Brookdale moved to compel Carlson and Quinlan to 
arbitrate based on their residency agreements.   
  The district court denied the motion to compel arbitration as to Carlson 
because Carlson’s earlier agreement to arbitrate was superseded by her most recent 
agreement’s opt-out.  We agree and affirm as to Carlson.   
In 2017, Carlson’s legal representative and power of attorney signed her most 
recent agreement, which “constitute[d] the entire agreement between the parties and 
supersede[d]  all  prior  and  contemporaneous  discussions,  representations, 
correspondence,  and  agreements  whether  oral  or  written.”    In  that  agreement, 
Carlson opted out of arbitration.  According to the terms of the agreement, it applied 
to “[a]ny and all claims or controversies arising out of, or in any way relating to, this 
Agreement or [Carlson’s] stay at [Brookdale] . . . whether existing or arising in the 
future.”     
2 
      

CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  33  ooff  66
In California, a court’s interpretation of a contract begins and ends with the 
language if the language is “clear and explicit.”  Cal. Civ. Code § 1638; see also 
Bank of the W. v. Superior Court, 833 P.2d 545, 552 (Cal. 1992).  Here, Carlson’s 
2017 residency agreement clearly covered any claims she may have had against 
Brookdale, including those existing at the time Carlson’s representative signed the 
agreement.  Accordingly, we affirm the district court’s denial of Brookdale’s motion 
to compel arbitration as to Carlson.  
We next consider Brookdale’s appeal as to Quinlan.  The district court denied 
Brookdale’s motion to compel Quinlan to arbitrate for two reasons: 1) because 
Quinlan’s son, who signed Quinlan’s residency agreement, did not have apparent 
authority to bind Quinlan; and 2) because Quinlan’s claims were extricable from the 
residency agreement, so equitable estoppel did not apply.   
We agree on the first point but disagree on the second.  Quinlan’s claims under 
the CLRA, the UCL, and section 15610.30 of the California Welfare and Institutions 
Code are founded on the residency agreement, but his claims under the ADA and 
the Unruh Act are not.  Accordingly, we affirm in part and reverse in part as to 
Quinlan.  
We hold that Quinlan’s son did not have apparent authority to bind Quinlan 
to the residency agreement.  Apparent authority arises when a principal’s actions 
would cause a reasonable person to believe that an agent had the authority to act for 
3 
      

CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  44  ooff  66
the principal.  Cal. Civ. Code § 2300; Mavrix Photographs, LLC v. LiveJournal, Inc., 
873  F.3d  1045,  1055  (9th  Cir.  2017).    Here,  Quinlan’s  son  signed  Quinlan’s 
residency  agreement,  including  on  lines  marked  “Legal  Representative,”  and 
Quinlan took no action to disclaim his son’s agency.  Quinlan’s silence, however, 
“communicated nothing” because there was no “historical relationship or course of 
conduct” that would allow Brookdale to infer such silence established apparent 
agency.  Valentine v. Plum Healthcare Grp., LLC, 249 Cal. Rptr. 3d 905, 914–15 
(Cal. Ct. App. 2019). 
We next hold that Quinlan is estopped from disclaiming the arbitration clause 
for his claims under the CLRA, UCL, and section 15610.30 of the California Welfare 
and Institutions Code (elder financial abuse).  Under California law, a litigant may 
not assert claims based on a contract while simultaneously arguing that an arbitration 
clause in that contract is ineffective.  See Kramer v. Toyota Motor Corp., 705 F.3d 
1122, 1128 (9th Cir. 2013).  The question is whether “the claims are ‘intimately 
founded in and intertwined with’ the underlying contract.”  Id. (quoting Goldman v. 
KPMG LLP, 92 Cal. Rptr. 3d 534, 543 (Cal. Ct. App. 2009)); see also Boucher v. 
All. Title Co., 25 Cal. Rptr. 3d 440, 447 (Cal. Ct. App. 2005) (applying equitable 
estoppel to a claim under the UCL). 
Here, Quinlan’s CLRA, UCL, and elder financial abuse claims are predicated 
on  the  allegation  that  Brookdale  did  not  perform  as  the  residency  agreement 
4 
      

CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  55  ooff  66
required.  Quinlan alleges that his son and granddaughter “read the agreement . . . 
and reasonably understood . . . that BROOKDALE would . . . provide the services 
that BROOKDALE promised and for which Mr. QUINLAN was paying.”  Quinlan 
then  pleads  these  claims  on  the  ground  that  the  agreement,  and  other 
communications  predominantly  derivative  of  the  transaction  such  as  resident 
evaluations and invoices, were “false and misleading.”  But the communications’ 
falsity is dependent on the allegation, reasserted in each of the three claims, that 
Brookdale’s policies failed “to ensure that all residents receive the services they have 
been promised and for which they are paying.”  We hold that Quinlan is estopped 
from disclaiming the arbitration clause in asserting his UCL, CLRA, and elder 
financial abuse claims because those claims are founded on the residency agreement. 
Quinlan’s claims under the ADA and the Unruh Act are different.  These 
claims as pleaded do not rest upon the residency agreement.  For example, the claim 
that Brookdale’s facilities must meet the access requirements under Title III of the 
ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12183(a)(1), is not “intertwined with” the agreement and thus 
Quinlan is not required to arbitrate this claim under principles of equitable estoppel.  
See Goldman, 92 Cal. Rptr. 3d at 543.  We therefore hold that Quinlan is not bound 
to arbitrate his ADA and Unruh Act claims. 
We  affirm  the  district  court’s  denial  of  Brookdale’s  motion  to  compel 
arbitration as to Helen Carlson’s claims and to Lawrence Quinlan’s ADA and Unruh 
5 
      

CCaassee :4 1:197-1-c5v3-3043,9 0642/-2H4S/2G0 2  0D, oIDcu: m11e6n7t 0168555  ,  FDilketdE n0t4ry/2: 44/22-01 ,   PPaaggee  66  ooff  66
Act claims.  We reverse the district court’s denial of Brookdale’s motion to compel 
arbitration as to Quinlan’s CLRA, UCL, and elder financial abuse claims. 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.1   
 
 
 
 
1 Each party shall bear its own costs. 
6
